17656.text: §¶The vision of Isaiah son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.

17657.text: §¶Hear, O heavens, and listen, O earth;/_for the Lord has spoken:/I reared children and brought them up,/_but they have rebelled against me.

17658.text: /The ox knows its owner,/_and the donkey its master’s crib;/but Israel does not know,/_my people do not understand.

17659.text: ¶Ah, sinful nation,/_people laden with iniquity,/offspring who do evil,/_children who deal corruptly,/who have forsaken the Lord,/_who have despised the Holy One of Israel,/_who are utterly estranged!

17660.text: ¶Why do you seek further beatings?/_Why do you continue to rebel?/The whole head is sick,/_and the whole heart faint.

17661.text: /From the sole of the foot even to the head,/_there is no soundness in it,/but bruises and sores/_and bleeding wounds;/they have not been drained, or bound up,/_or softened with oil.

17662.text: ¶Your country lies desolate,/_your cities are burned with fire;/in your very presence/_aliens devour your land;/_it is desolate, as overthrown by foreigners.

17663.text: /And daughter Zion is left/_like a booth in a vineyard,/like a shelter in a cucumber field,/_like a besieged city.

17664.text: /If the Lord of hosts/_had not left us a few survivors,/we would have been like Sodom,/_and become like Gomorrah.

17665.text: ¶Hear the word of the Lord,/_you rulers of Sodom!/Listen to the teaching of our God,/_you people of Gomorrah!

17666.text: /What to me is the multitude of your sacrifices?/_says the Lord;/I have had enough of burnt offerings of rams/_and the fat of fed beasts;/I do not delight in the blood of bulls,/_or of lambs, or of goats.

17667.text: ¶When you come to appear before me,/_who asked this from your hand?/_Trample my courts no more;

17668.text: /bringing offerings is futile;/_incense is an abomination to me./New moon and sabbath and calling of convocation—/_I cannot endure solemn assemblies with iniquity.

17669.text: /Your new moons and your appointed festivals/_my soul hates;/they have become a burden to me,/_I am weary of bearing them.

17670.text: /When you stretch out your hands,/_I will hide my eyes from you;/even though you make many prayers,/_I will not listen;/_your hands are full of blood.

17671.text: /Wash yourselves; make yourselves clean;/_remove the evil of your doings/_from before my eyes;/cease to do evil,

17672.text: /_learn to do good;/seek justice,/_rescue the oppressed,/defend the orphan,/_plead for the widow.

17673.text: ¶Come now, let us argue it out,/_says the Lord:/though your sins are like scarlet,/_they shall be like snow;/though they are red like crimson,/_they shall become like wool.

17674.text: /If you are willing and obedient,/_you shall eat the good of the land;

17675.text: /but if you refuse and rebel,/_you shall be devoured by the sword;/_for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.

17676.text: §¶How the faithful city/_has become a whore!/_She that was full of justice,/righteousness lodged in her—/_but now murderers!

17677.text: /Your silver has become dross,/_your wine is mixed with water.

17678.text: /Your princes are rebels/_and companions of thieves./Everyone loves a bribe/_and runs after gifts./They do not defend the orphan,/_and the widow’s cause does not come before them.

17679.text: ¶Therefore says the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel:/Ah, I will pour out my wrath on my enemies,/_and avenge myself on my foes!

17680.text: /I will turn my hand against you;/_I will smelt away your dross as with lye/_and remove all your alloy.

17681.text: /And I will restore your judges as at the first,/_and your counselors as at the beginning./Afterward you shall be called the city of righteousness,/_the faithful city.

17682.text: ¶Zion shall be redeemed by justice,/_and those in her who repent, by righteousness.

17683.text: /But rebels and sinners shall be destroyed together,/_and those who forsake the Lord shall be consumed.

17684.text: /For you shall be ashamed of the oaks/_in which you delighted;/and you shall blush for the gardens/_that you have chosen.

17685.text: /For you shall be like an oak/_whose leaf withers,/_and like a garden without water.

17686.text: /The strong shall become like tinder,/_and their work like a spark;/they and their work shall burn together,/_with no one to quench them.

17687.text: §¶The word that Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem.

17688.text: ¶In days to come/_the mountain of the Lord’s house/shall be established as the highest of the mountains,/_and shall be raised above the hills;/all the nations shall stream to it.

17689.text: /_Many peoples shall come and say,/“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,/_to the house of the God of Jacob;/that he may teach us his ways/_and that we may walk in his paths.”/For out of Zion shall go forth instruction,/_and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

17690.text: /He shall judge between the nations,/_and shall arbitrate for many peoples;/they shall beat their swords into plowshares,/_and their spears into pruning hooks;/nation shall not lift up sword against nation,/_neither shall they learn war any more.

17691.text: §¶O house of Jacob,/_come, let us walk/_in the light of the Lord!

17692.text: /For you have forsaken the ways of your people,/_O house of Jacob./Indeed they are full of diviners from the east/_and of soothsayers like the Philistines,/_and they clasp hands with foreigners.

17693.text: /Their land is filled with silver and gold,/_and there is no end to their treasures;/their land is filled with horses,/_and there is no end to their chariots.

17694.text: /Their land is filled with idols;/_they bow down to the work of their hands,/_to what their own fingers have made.

17695.text: /And so people are humbled,/_and everyone is brought low—/_do not forgive them!

17696.text: /Enter into the rock,/_and hide in the dust/from the terror of the Lord,/_and from the glory of his majesty.

17697.text: /The haughty eyes of people shall be brought low,/_and the pride of everyone shall be humbled;/and the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.

17698.text: /For the Lord of hosts has a day/_against all that is proud and lofty,/_against all that is lifted up and high;

17699.text: /against all the cedars of Lebanon,/_lofty and lifted up;/_and against all the oaks of Bashan;

17700.text: /against all the high mountains,/_and against all the lofty hills;

17701.text: /against every high tower,/_and against every fortified wall;

17702.text: /against all the ships of Tarshish,/_and against all the beautiful craft.

17703.text: /The haughtiness of people shall be humbled,/_and the pride of everyone shall be brought low;/_and the Lord alone will be exalted on that day.

17705.text: /Enter the caves of the rocks/_and the holes of the ground,/from the terror of the Lord,/_and from the glory of his majesty,/_when he rises to terrify the earth.

17706.text: /On that day people will throw away/_to the moles and to the bats/their idols of silver and their idols of gold,/_which they made for themselves to worship,

17707.text: /to enter the caverns of the rocks/_and the clefts in the crags,/from the terror of the Lord,/_and from the glory of his majesty,/_when he rises to terrify the earth.

17708.text: /Turn away from mortals,/_who have only breath in their nostrils,/_for of what account are they?

17709.text: /For now the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts,/_is taking away from Jerusalem and from Judah/support and staff—/_all support of bread,/_and all support of water—

17710.text: /warrior and soldier,/_judge and prophet,/_diviner and elder,

17711.text: /captain of fifty/_and dignitary,/counselor and skillful magician/_and expert enchanter.

17712.text: /And I will make boys their princes,/_and babes shall rule over them.

17713.text: /The people will be oppressed,/_everyone by another/_and everyone by a neighbor;/the youth will be insolent to the elder,/_and the base to the honorable.

17714.text: ¶Someone will even seize a relative,/_a member of the clan, saying,/“You have a cloak;/_you shall be our leader,/and this heap of ruins/_shall be under your rule.”

17715.text: /But the other will cry out on that day, saying,/“I will not be a healer;/_in my house there is neither bread nor cloak;/you shall not make me/_leader of the people.”

17716.text: /For Jerusalem has stumbled/_and Judah has fallen,/because their speech and their deeds are against the Lord,/_defying his glorious presence.

17717.text: ¶The look on their faces bears witness against them;/_they proclaim their sin like Sodom,/_they do not hide it./Woe to them!/_For they have brought evil on themselves.

17718.text: /Tell the innocent how fortunate they are,/_for they shall eat the fruit of their labors.

17719.text: /Woe to the guilty! How unfortunate they are,/_for what their hands have done shall be done to them.

17720.text: /My people—children are their oppressors,/_and women rule over them./O my people, your leaders mislead you,/_and confuse the course of your paths.

17721.text: ¶The Lord rises to argue his case;/_he stands to judge the peoples.

17722.text: /The Lord enters into judgment/_with the elders and princes of his people:/It is you who have devoured the vineyard;/_the spoil of the poor is in your houses.

17723.text: /What do you mean by crushing my people,/_by grinding the face of the poor? says the Lord God of hosts.

17724.text: ¶The Lord said:/Because the daughters of Zion are haughty/_and walk with outstretched necks,/_glancing wantonly with their eyes,/mincing along as they go,/_tinkling with their feet;

17725.text: /the Lord will afflict with scabs/_the heads of the daughters of Zion,/_and the Lord will lay bare their secret parts.

17726.text: ¶In that day the Lord will take away the finery of the anklets, the headbands, and the crescents;

17727.text: the pendants, the bracelets, and the scarfs;

17728.text: the headdresses, the armlets, the sashes, the perfume boxes, and the amulets;

17729.text: the signet rings and nose rings;

17730.text: the festal robes, the mantles, the cloaks, and the handbags;

17731.text: the garments of gauze, the linen garments, the turbans, and the veils.

17732.text: ¶Instead of perfume there will be a stench;/_and instead of a sash, a rope;/and instead of well‐set hair, baldness;/_and instead of a rich robe, a binding of sackcloth;/_instead of beauty, shame.

17733.text: /Your men shall fall by the sword/_and your warriors in battle.

17734.text: /And her gates shall lament and mourn;/_ravaged, she shall sit upon the ground.

17735.text: ¶Seven women shall take hold of one man in that day, saying,¶▼“We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes;/just let us be called by your name;/_take away our disgrace.”

17736.text: §¶On that day the branch of the Lord shall be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land shall be the pride and glory of the survivors of Israel.

17737.text: Whoever is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who has been recorded for life in Jerusalem,

17738.text: once the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and cleansed the bloodstains of Jerusalem from its midst by a spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning.

17739.text: Then the Lord will create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over its places of assembly a cloud by day and smoke and the shining of a flaming fire by night. Indeed over all the glory there will be a canopy.

17740.text: It will serve as a pavilion, a shade by day from the heat, and a refuge and a shelter from the storm and rain.

17912.text: /They come from a distant land,/_from the end of the heavens,/the Lord and the weapons of his indignation,/_to destroy the whole earth.

17913.text: ¶Wail, for the day of the Lord is near;/_it will come like destruction from the Almighty!

17914.text: /Therefore all hands will be feeble,/_and every human heart will melt,

17915.text: /_and they will be dismayed./Pangs and agony will seize them;/_they will be in anguish like a woman in labor./They will look aghast at one another;/_their faces will be aflame.

17916.text: /See, the day of the Lord comes,/_cruel, with wrath and fierce anger,/to make the earth a desolation,/_and to destroy its sinners from it.

17917.text: /For the stars of the heavens and their constellations/_will not give their light;/the sun will be dark at its rising,/_and the moon will not shed its light.

17918.text: /I will punish the world for its evil,/_and the wicked for their iniquity;/I will put an end to the pride of the arrogant,/_and lay low the insolence of tyrants.

17919.text: /I will make mortals more rare than fine gold,/_and humans than the gold of Ophir.

17920.text: /Therefore I will make the heavens tremble,/_and the earth will be shaken out of its place,/at the wrath of the Lord of hosts/_in the day of his fierce anger.

17921.text: /Like a hunted gazelle,/_or like sheep with no one to gather them,/all will turn to their own people,/_and all will flee to their own lands.

17922.text: /Whoever is found will be thrust through,/_and whoever is caught will fall by the sword.

17923.text: /Their infants will be dashed to pieces/_before their eyes;/their houses will be plundered,/_and their wives ravished.

17924.text: /See, I am stirring up the Medes against them,/_who have no regard for silver/_and do not delight in gold.

17925.text: /Their bows will slaughter the young men;/_they will have no mercy on the fruit of the womb;/_their eyes will not pity children.

17926.text: /And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms,/_the splendor and pride of the Chaldeans,/will be like Sodom and Gomorrah/_when God overthrew them.

17927.text: /It will never be inhabited/_or lived in for all generations;/Arabs will not pitch their tents there,/_shepherds will not make their flocks lie down there.

17928.text: /But wild animals will lie down there,/_and its houses will be full of howling creatures;/there ostriches will live,/_and there goat‑demons will dance.

17929.text: /Hyenas will cry in its towers,/_and jackals in the pleasant palaces;/its time is close at hand,/_and its days will not be prolonged.

17930.text: §¶But the Lord will have compassion on Jacob and will again choose Israel, and will set them in their own land; and aliens will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.

17931.text: And the nations will take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will possess the nations as male and female slaves in the Lord’s land; they will take captive those who were their captors, and rule over those who oppressed them.

17932.text: §¶When the Lord has given you rest from your pain and turmoil and the hard service with which you were made to serve,

17933.text: you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon:¶▼How the oppressor has ceased!/_How his insolence has ceased!

17934.text: /The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked,/_the scepter of rulers,

17935.text: /that struck down the peoples in wrath/_with unceasing blows,/that ruled the nations in anger/_with unrelenting persecution.

17936.text: /The whole earth is at rest and quiet;/_they break forth into singing.

17937.text: /The cypresses exult over you,/_the cedars of Lebanon, saying,/“Since you were laid low,/_no one comes to cut us down.”

17938.text: /Sheol beneath is stirred up/_to meet you when you come;/it rouses the shades to greet you,/_all who were leaders of the earth;/it raises from their thrones/_all who were kings of the nations.

17939.text: /All of them will speak/_and say to you:/“You too have become as weak as we!/_You have become like us!”

17940.text: /Your pomp is brought down to Sheol,/_and the sound of your harps;/maggots are the bed beneath you,/_and worms are your covering.

17941.text: ¶How you are fallen from heaven,/_O Day Star, son of Dawn!/How you are cut down to the ground,/_you who laid the nations low!

17942.text: /You said in your heart,/_“I will ascend to heaven;/I will raise my throne/_above the stars of God;/I will sit on the mount of assembly/_on the heights of Zaphon;

17943.text: /I will ascend to the tops of the clouds,/_I will make myself like the Most High.”

17944.text: /But you are brought down to Sheol,/_to the depths of the Pit.

17945.text: /Those who see you will stare at you,/_and ponder over you:/“Is this the man who made the earth tremble,/_who shook kingdoms,

17946.text: /who made the world like a desert/_and overthrew its cities,/_who would not let his prisoners go home?”

17947.text: /All the kings of the nations lie in glory,/_each in his own tomb;

17948.text: /but you are cast out, away from your grave,/_like loathsome carrion,/clothed with the dead, those pierced by the sword,/_who go down to the stones of the Pit,/_like a corpse trampled underfoot.

17949.text: /You will not be joined with them in burial,/_because you have destroyed your land,/_you have killed your people.¶May the descendants of evildoers/_nevermore be named!

17950.text: /Prepare slaughter for his sons/_because of the guilt of their father./Let them never rise to possess the earth/_or cover the face of the world with cities.

17951.text: ¶I will rise up against them, says the Lord of hosts, and will cut off from Babylon name and remnant, offspring and posterity, says the Lord.

17952.text: And I will make it a possession of the hedgehog, and pools of water, and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction, says the Lord of hosts.

17953.text: §¶The Lord of hosts has sworn:/As I have designed,/_so shall it be;/and as I have planned,/_so shall it come to pass:

17954.text: /I will break the Assyrian in my land,/_and on my mountains trample him under foot;/his yoke shall be removed from them,/_and his burden from their shoulders.

17955.text: /This is the plan that is planned/_concerning the whole earth;/and this is the hand that is stretched out/_over all the nations.

17956.text: /For the Lord of hosts has planned,/_and who will annul it?/His hand is stretched out,/_and who will turn it back?

17957.text: §¶In the year that King Ahaz died this oracle came:

17958.text: ¶Do not rejoice, all you Philistines,/_that the rod that struck you is broken,/for from the root of the snake will come forth an adder,/_and its fruit will be a flying fiery serpent.

17959.text: /The firstborn of the poor will graze,/_and the needy lie down in safety;/but I will make your root die of famine,/_and your remnant I will kill.

17960.text: /Wail, O gate; cry, O city;/_melt in fear, O Philistia, all of you!/For smoke comes out of the north,/_and there is no straggler in its ranks.

17961.text: ¶What will one answer the messengers of the nation?/“The Lord has founded Zion,/_and the needy among his people/_will find refuge in her.”

17962.text: §¶An oracle concerning Moab.¶▼Because Ar is laid waste in a night,/_Moab is undone;/because Kir is laid waste in a night,/_Moab is undone.

17963.text: /Dibon has gone up to the temple,/_to the high places to weep;/over Nebo and over Medeba/_Moab wails./On every head is baldness,/_every beard is shorn;

17964.text: /in the streets they bind on sackcloth;/_on the housetops and in the squares/_everyone wails and melts in tears.

17965.text: /Heshbon and Elealeh cry out,/_their voices are heard as far as Jahaz;/therefore the loins of Moab quiver;/_his soul trembles.

17966.text: /My heart cries out for Moab;/_his fugitives flee to Zoar,/_to Eglath‑shelishiyah./For at the ascent of Luhith/_they go up weeping;/on the road to Horonaim/_they raise a cry of destruction;

17967.text: /the waters of Nimrim/_are a desolation;/the grass is withered, the new growth fails,/_the verdure is no more.

17968.text: /Therefore the abundance they have gained/_and what they have laid up/they carry away/_over the Wadi of the Willows.

17969.text: /For a cry has gone/_around the land of Moab;/the wailing reaches to Eglaim,/_the wailing reaches to Beer‑elim.

17970.text: /For the waters of Dibon are full of blood;/_yet I will bring upon Dibon even more—/a lion for those of Moab who escape,/_for the remnant of the land.

17971.text: /Send lambs/_to the ruler of the land,/from Sela, by way of the desert,/_to the mount of daughter Zion.

17972.text: /Like fluttering birds,/_like scattered nestlings,/so are the daughters of Moab/_at the fords of the Arnon.

17973.text: /“Give counsel,/_grant justice;/make your shade like night/_at the height of noon;/hide the outcasts,/_do not betray the fugitive;

17974.text: /let the outcasts of Moab/_settle among you;/be a refuge to them/_from the destroyer.”¶When the oppressor is no more,/_and destruction has ceased,/and marauders have vanished from the land,

17975.text: /then a throne shall be established in steadfast love/_in the tent of David,/_and on it shall sit in faithfulness/a ruler who seeks justice/_and is swift to do what is right.

17976.text: ¶We have heard of the pride of Moab/_—how proud he is!—/of his arrogance, his pride, and his insolence;/_his boasts are false.

17977.text: /Therefore let Moab wail,/_let everyone wail for Moab./Mourn, utterly stricken,/_for the raisin cakes of Kir‑hareseth.

17978.text: ¶For the fields of Heshbon languish,/_and the vines of Sibmah,/whose clusters once made drunk/_the lords of the nations,/reached to Jazer/_and strayed to the desert;/their shoots once spread abroad/_and crossed over the sea.

17979.text: /Therefore I weep with the weeping of Jazer/_for the vines of Sibmah;/I drench you with my tears,/_O Heshbon and Elealeh;/for the shout over your fruit harvest/_and your grain harvest has ceased.

17980.text: /Joy and gladness are taken away/_from the fruitful field;/and in the vineyards no songs are sung,/_no shouts are raised;/no treader treads out wine in the presses;/_the vintage‑shout is hushed.

17981.text: /Therefore my heart throbs like a harp for Moab,/_and my very soul for Kir‑heres.

17982.text: ¶When Moab presents himself, when he wearies himself upon the high place, when he comes to his sanctuary to pray, he will not prevail.

17983.text: ¶This was the word that the Lord spoke concerning Moab in the past.

17984.text: But now the Lord says, In three years, like the years of a hired worker, the glory of Moab will be brought into contempt, in spite of all its great multitude; and those who survive will be very few and feeble.

17985.text: §¶An oracle concerning Damascus.¶▼See, Damascus will cease to be a city,/_and will become a heap of ruins.

17986.text: /Her towns will be deserted forever;/_they will be places for flocks,/_which will lie down, and no one will make them afraid.

17987.text: /The fortress will disappear from Ephraim,/_and the kingdom from Damascus;/and the remnant of Aram will be/_like the glory of the children of Israel,/says the Lord of hosts.

17988.text: ¶On that day/_the glory of Jacob will be brought low,/_and the fat of his flesh will grow lean.

17989.text: /And it shall be as when reapers gather standing grain/_and their arms harvest the ears,/and as when one gleans the ears of grain/_in the Valley of Rephaim.

17990.text: /Gleanings will be left in it,/_as when an olive tree is beaten—/two or three berries/_in the top of the highest bough,/four or five/_on the branches of a fruit tree,/says the Lord God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶On that day people will regard their Maker, and their eyes will look to the Holy One of Israel;

17992.text: they will not have regard for the altars, the work of their hands, and they will not look to what their own fingers have made, either the sacred poles or the altars of incense.

17993.text: ¶On that day their strong cities will be like the deserted places of the Hivites and the Amorites, which they deserted because of the children of Israel, and there will be desolation.

17994.text: ¶For you have forgotten the God of your salvation,/_and have not remembered the Rock of your refuge;/therefore, though you plant pleasant plants/_and set out slips of an alien god,

17995.text: /though you make them grow on the day that you plant them,/_and make them blossom in the morning that you sow;/yet the harvest will flee away/_in a day of grief and incurable pain.

17996.text: ¶Ah, the thunder of many peoples,/_they thunder like the thundering of the sea!/Ah, the roar of nations,/_they roar like the roaring of mighty waters!

17997.text: /The nations roar like the roaring of many waters,/_but he will rebuke them, and they will flee far away,/chased like chaff on the mountains before the wind/_and whirling dust before the storm.

17998.text: /At evening time, lo, terror!/_Before morning, they are no more./This is the fate of those who despoil us,/_and the lot of those who plunder us.

17999.text: §¶Ah, land of whirring wings/_beyond the rivers of Ethiopia,

18000.text: /sending ambassadors by the Nile/_in vessels of papyrus on the waters!/Go, you swift messengers,/_to a nation tall and smooth,/to a people feared near and far,/_a nation mighty and conquering,/_whose land the rivers divide.

18001.text: ¶All you inhabitants of the world,/_you who live on the earth,/when a signal is raised on the mountains, look!/_When a trumpet is blown, listen!

18002.text: /For thus the Lord said to me:/I will quietly look from my dwelling/_like clear heat in sunshine,/_like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.

18003.text: /For before the harvest, when the blossom is over/_and the flower becomes a ripening grape,/he will cut off the shoots with pruning hooks,/_and the spreading branches he will hew away.

18004.text: /They shall all be left/_to the birds of prey of the mountains/_and to the animals of the earth./And the birds of prey will summer on them,/_and all the animals of the earth will winter on them.

18005.text: ¶At that time gifts will be brought to the Lord of hosts from a people tall and smooth, from a people feared near and far, a nation mighty and conquering, whose land the rivers divide, to Mount Zion, the place of the name of the Lord of hosts.

18006.text: §¶An oracle concerning Egypt.¶▼See, the Lord is riding on a swift cloud/_and comes to Egypt;/the idols of Egypt will tremble at his presence,/_and the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them.

18007.text: /I will stir up Egyptians against Egyptians,/_and they will fight, one against the other,/_neighbor against neighbor,/_city against city, kingdom against kingdom;

18008.text: /the spirit of the Egyptians within them will be emptied out,/_and I will confound their plans;/they will consult the idols and the spirits of the dead/_and the ghosts and the familiar spirits;

18009.text: /I will deliver the Egyptians/_into the hand of a hard master;/a fierce king will rule over them,/_says the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts.

18010.text: ¶The waters of the Nile will be dried up,/_and the river will be parched and dry;

18011.text: /its canals will become foul,/_and the branches of Egypt’s Nile will diminish and dry up,/_reeds and rushes will rot away.

18012.text: /There will be bare places by the Nile,/_on the brink of the Nile;/and all that is sown by the Nile will dry up,/_be driven away, and be no more.

18013.text: /Those who fish will mourn;/_all who cast hooks in the Nile will lament,/_and those who spread nets on the water will languish.

18014.text: /The workers in flax will be in despair,/_and the carders and those at the loom will grow pale.

18015.text: /Its weavers will be dismayed,/_and all who work for wages will be grieved.

18016.text: ¶The princes of Zoan are utterly foolish;/_the wise counselors of Pharaoh give stupid counsel./How can you say to Pharaoh,/_“I am one of the sages,/_a descendant of ancient kings”?

18017.text: /Where now are your sages?/_Let them tell you and make known/_what the Lord of hosts has planned against Egypt.

18018.text: /The princes of Zoan have become fools,/_and the princes of Memphis are deluded;/those who are the cornerstones of its tribes/_have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: /The Lord has poured into them/_a spirit of confusion;/and they have made Egypt stagger in all its doings/_as a drunkard staggers around in vomit.

18020.text: /Neither head nor tail, palm branch or reed,/_will be able to do anything for Egypt.

18021.text: ¶On that day the Egyptians will be like women, and tremble with fear before the hand that the Lord of hosts raises against them.

18022.text: And the land of Judah will become a terror to the Egyptians; everyone to whom it is mentioned will fear because of the plan that the Lord of hosts is planning against them.

18023.text: §¶On that day there will be five cities in the land of Egypt that speak the language of Canaan and swear allegiance to the Lord of hosts. One of these will be called the City of the Sun.

18024.text: ¶On that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the center of the land of Egypt, and a pillar to the Lord at its border.

18025.text: It will be a sign and a witness to the Lord of hosts in the land of Egypt; when they cry to the Lord because of oppressors, he will send them a savior, and will defend and deliver them.

18026.text: The Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians; and the Egyptians will know the Lord on that day, and will worship with sacrifice and burnt offering, and they will make vows to the Lord and perform them.

18027.text: The Lord will strike Egypt, striking and healing; they will return to the Lord, and he will listen to their supplications and heal them.

18028.text: ¶On that day there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrian will come into Egypt, and the Egyptian into Assyria, and the Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.

18029.text: ¶On that day Israel will be the third with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing in the midst of the earth,

18030.text: whom the Lord of hosts has blessed, saying, “Blessed be Egypt my people, and Assyria the work of my hands, and Israel my heritage.”

18031.text: §¶In the year that the commander‑in‑chief, who was sent by King Sargon of Assyria, came to Ashdod and fought against it and took it—

18032.text: at that time the Lord had spoken to Isaiah son of Amoz, saying, “Go, and loose the sackcloth from your loins and take your sandals off your feet,” and he had done so, walking naked and barefoot.

18033.text: Then the Lord said, “Just as my servant Isaiah has walked naked and barefoot for three years as a sign and a portent against Egypt and Ethiopia,

18034.text: so shall the king of Assyria lead away the Egyptians as captives and the Ethiopians as exiles, both the young and the old, naked and barefoot, with buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.

18035.text: And they shall be dismayed and confounded because of Ethiopia their hope and of Egypt their boast.

18036.text: In that day the inhabitants of this coastland will say, ‘See, this is what has happened to those in whom we hoped and to whom we fled for help and deliverance from the king of Assyria! And we, how shall we escape?’”

18037.text: §¶The oracle concerning the wilderness of the sea.¶▼As whirlwinds in the Negeb sweep on,/_it comes from the desert,/_from a terrible land.

18038.text: /A stern vision is told to me;/_the betrayer betrays,/_and the destroyer destroys./Go up, O Elam,/_lay siege, O Media;/all the sighing she has caused/_I bring to an end.

18039.text: /Therefore my loins are filled with anguish;/_pangs have seized me,/_like the pangs of a woman in labor;/I am bowed down so that I cannot hear,/_I am dismayed so that I cannot see.

18040.text: /My mind reels, horror has appalled me;/_the twilight I longed for/_has been turned for me into trembling.

18041.text: /They prepare the table,/_they spread the rugs,/_they eat, they drink./Rise up, commanders,/_oil the shield!

18042.text: /For thus the Lord said to me:/“Go, post a lookout,/_let him announce what he sees.

18043.text: /When he sees riders, horsemen in pairs,/_riders on donkeys, riders on camels,/let him listen diligently,/_very diligently.”

18044.text: /Then the watcher called out:/“Upon a watchtower I stand, O Lord,/_continually by day,/and at my post I am stationed/_throughout the night.

18045.text: /Look, there they come, riders,/_horsemen in pairs!”/Then he responded,/_“Fallen, fallen is Babylon;/and all the images of her gods/_lie shattered on the ground.”

18046.text: /O my threshed and winnowed one,/_what I have heard from the Lord of hosts,/_the God of Israel, I announce to you.

18047.text: ¶The oracle concerning Dumah.¶▼One is calling to me from Seir,/_“Sentinel, what of the night?/_Sentinel, what of the night?”

18048.text: /The sentinel says:/“Morning comes, and also the night./_If you will inquire, inquire;/_come back again.”

18049.text: ¶The oracle concerning the desert plain.¶▼In the scrub of the desert plain you will lodge,/_O caravans of Dedanites.

18050.text: /Bring water to the thirsty,/_meet the fugitive with bread,/_O inhabitants of the land of Tema.

18051.text: /For they have fled from the swords,/_from the drawn sword,/from the bent bow,/_and from the stress of battle.

18052.text: ¶For thus the Lord said to me: Within a year, according to the years of a hired worker, all the glory of Kedar will come to an end;

18053.text: and the remaining bows of Kedar’s warriors will be few; for the Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken.

18054.text: §¶The oracle concerning the valley of vision.¶▼What do you mean that you have gone up,/_all of you, to the housetops,

18055.text: /you that are full of shoutings,/_tumultuous city, exultant town?/Your slain are not slain by the sword,/_nor are they dead in battle.

18056.text: /Your rulers have all fled together;/_they were captured without the use of a bow./All of you who were found were captured,/_though they had fled far away.

18057.text: /Therefore I said:/Look away from me,/_let me weep bitter tears;/do not try to comfort me/_for the destruction of my beloved people.

18058.text: ¶For the Lord God of hosts has a day/_of tumult and trampling and confusion/_in the valley of vision,/a battering down of walls/_and a cry for help to the mountains.

18059.text: /Elam bore the quiver/_with chariots and cavalry,/_and Kir uncovered the shield.

18060.text: /Your choicest valleys were full of chariots,/_and the cavalry took their stand at the gates.

18061.text: /He has taken away the covering of Judah.¶►On that day you looked to the weapons of the House of the Forest,

18062.text: and you saw that there were many breaches in the city of David, and you collected the waters of the lower pool.

18063.text: You counted the houses of Jerusalem, and you broke down the houses to fortify the wall.

18064.text: You made a reservoir between the two walls for the water of the old pool. But you did not look to him who did it, or have regard for him who planned it long ago.

18065.text: ¶In that day the Lord God of hosts/_called to weeping and mourning,/_to baldness and putting on sackcloth;

18066.text: /but instead there was joy and festivity,/_killing oxen and slaughtering sheep,/_eating meat and drinking wine./“Let us eat and drink,/_for tomorrow we die.”

18067.text: /The Lord of hosts has revealed himself in my ears:/Surely this iniquity will not be forgiven you until you die,/_says the Lord God of hosts.

18068.text: §¶Thus says the Lord God of hosts: Come, go to this steward, to Shebna, who is master of the household, and say to him:

18069.text: What right do you have here? Who are your relatives here, that you have cut out a tomb here for yourself, cutting a tomb on the height, and carving a habitation for yourself in the rock?

18070.text: The Lord is about to hurl you away violently, my fellow. He will seize firm hold on you,

18071.text: whirl you round and round, and throw you like a ball into a wide land; there you shall die, and there your splendid chariots shall lie, O you disgrace to your master’s house!

18072.text: I will thrust you from your office, and you will be pulled down from your post.

18073.text: ¶On that day I will call my servant Eliakim son of Hilkiah,

18074.text: and will clothe him with your robe and bind your sash on him. I will commit your authority to his hand, and he shall be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.

18075.text: I will place on his shoulder the key of the house of David; he shall open, and no one shall shut; he shall shut, and no one shall open.

18076.text: I will fasten him like a peg in a secure place, and he will become a throne of honor to his ancestral house.

18077.text: And they will hang on him the whole weight of his ancestral house, the offspring and issue, every small vessel, from the cups to all the flagons.

18078.text: On that day, says the Lord of hosts, the peg that was fastened in a secure place will give way; it will be cut down and fall, and the load that was on it will perish, for the Lord has spoken.

18079.text: §¶The oracle concerning Tyre.¶▼Wail, O ships of Tarshish,/_for your fortress is destroyed./When they came in from Cyprus/_they learned of it.

18080.text: /Be still, O inhabitants of the coast,/_O merchants of Sidon,/your messengers crossed over the sea

18081.text: /_and were on the mighty waters;/your revenue was the grain of Shihor,/_the harvest of the Nile;/_you were the merchant of the nations.

18082.text: /Be ashamed, O Sidon, for the sea has spoken,/_the fortress of the sea, saying:/“I have neither labored nor given birth,/_I have neither reared young men/_nor brought up young women.”

18083.text: /When the report comes to Egypt,/_they will be in anguish over the report about Tyre.

18084.text: /Cross over to Tarshish—/_wail, O inhabitants of the coast!

18085.text: /Is this your exultant city/_whose origin is from days of old,/whose feet carried her/_to settle far away?

18086.text: /Who has planned this/_against Tyre, the bestower of crowns,/whose merchants were princes,/_whose traders were the honored of the earth?

18087.text: /The Lord of hosts has planned it—/_to defile the pride of all glory,/_to shame all the honored of the earth.

18088.text: /Cross over to your own land,/_O ships of Tarshish;/_this is a harbor no more.

18089.text: /He has stretched out his hand over the sea,/_he has shaken the kingdoms;/the Lord has given command concerning Canaan/_to destroy its fortresses.

18090.text: /He said:/You will exult no longer,/_O oppressed virgin daughter Sidon;/rise, cross over to Cyprus—/_even there you will have no rest.

18091.text: ¶Look at the land of the Chaldeans! This is the people; it was not Assyria. They destined Tyre for wild animals. They erected their siege towers, they tore down her palaces, they made her a ruin.

18092.text: ¶Wail, O ships of Tarshish,/_for your fortress is destroyed.

18093.text: ¶From that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, the lifetime of one king. At the end of seventy years, it will happen to Tyre as in the song about the prostitute:

18094.text: ¶Take a harp,/_go about the city,/_you forgotten prostitute!/Make sweet melody,/_sing many songs,/_that you may be remembered.

18095.text: ¶At the end of seventy years, the Lord will visit Tyre, and she will return to her trade, and will prostitute herself with all the kingdoms of the world on the face of the earth.

18096.text: Her merchandise and her wages will be dedicated to the Lord; her profits will not be stored or hoarded, but her merchandise will supply abundant food and fine clothing for those who live in the presence of the Lord.

18097.text: §¶Now the Lord is about to lay waste the earth and make it desolate,/_and he will twist its surface and scatter its inhabitants.

18098.text: /And it shall be, as with the people, so with the priest;/_as with the slave, so with his master;/_as with the maid, so with her mistress;/as with the buyer, so with the seller;/_as with the lender, so with the borrower;/_as with the creditor, so with the debtor.

18099.text: /The earth shall be utterly laid waste and utterly despoiled;/_for the Lord has spoken this word.

18100.text: ¶The earth dries up and withers,/_the world languishes and withers;/_the heavens languish together with the earth.

18101.text: /The earth lies polluted/_under its inhabitants;/for they have transgressed laws,/_violated the statutes,/_broken the everlasting covenant.

18102.text: /Therefore a curse devours the earth,/_and its inhabitants suffer for their guilt;/therefore the inhabitants of the earth dwindled,/_and few people are left.

18103.text: /The wine dries up,/_the vine languishes,/_all the merry‑hearted sigh.

18104.text: /The mirth of the timbrels is stilled,/_the noise of the jubilant has ceased,/_the mirth of the lyre is stilled.

18105.text: /No longer do they drink wine with singing;/_strong drink is bitter to those who drink it.

18106.text: /The city of chaos is broken down,/_every house is shut up so that no one can enter.

18107.text: /There is an outcry in the streets for lack of wine;/_all joy has reached its eventide;/_the gladness of the earth is banished.

18108.text: /Desolation is left in the city,/_the gates are battered into ruins.

18109.text: /For thus it shall be on the earth/_and among the nations,/as when an olive tree is beaten,/_as at the gleaning when the grape harvest is ended.

18110.text: ¶They lift up their voices, they sing for joy;/_they shout from the west over the majesty of the Lord.

18111.text: /Therefore in the east give glory to the Lord;/_in the coastlands of the sea glorify the name of the Lord, the God of Israel.

18112.text: /From the ends of the earth we hear songs of praise,/_of glory to the Righteous One./But I say, I pine away,/_I pine away. Woe is me!/For the treacherous deal treacherously,/_the treacherous deal very treacherously.

18113.text: ¶Terror, and the pit, and the snare/_are upon you, O inhabitant of the earth!

18114.text: /Whoever flees at the sound of the terror/_shall fall into the pit;/and whoever climbs out of the pit/_shall be caught in the snare./For the windows of heaven are opened,/_and the foundations of the earth tremble.

18115.text: /The earth is utterly broken,/_the earth is torn asunder,/_the earth is violently shaken.

18116.text: /The earth staggers like a drunkard,/_it sways like a hut;/its transgression lies heavy upon it,/_and it falls, and will not rise again.

18117.text: ¶On that day the Lord will punish/_the host of heaven in heaven,/_and on earth the kings of the earth.

18118.text: /They will be gathered together/_like prisoners in a pit;/they will be shut up in a prison,/_and after many days they will be punished.

18119.text: /Then the moon will be abashed,/_and the sun ashamed;/for the Lord of hosts will reign/_on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem,/and before his elders he will manifest his glory.

18120.text: §¶O Lord, you are my God;/_I will exalt you, I will praise your name;/for you have done wonderful things,/_plans formed of old, faithful and sure.

18121.text: /For you have made the city a heap,/_the fortified city a ruin;/the palace of aliens is a city no more,/_it will never be rebuilt.

18122.text: /Therefore strong peoples will glorify you;/_cities of ruthless nations will fear you.

18123.text: /For you have been a refuge to the poor,/_a refuge to the needy in their distress,/_a shelter from the rainstorm and a shade from the heat./When the blast of the ruthless was like a winter rainstorm,

18124.text: /_the noise of aliens like heat in a dry place,/you subdued the heat with the shade of clouds;/_the song of the ruthless was stilled.

18125.text: ¶On this mountain the Lord of hosts will make for all peoples/_a feast of rich food, a feast of well‑aged wines,/_of rich food filled with marrow, of well‑aged wines strained clear.

18126.text: /And he will destroy on this mountain/_the shroud that is cast over all peoples,/_the sheet that is spread over all nations;

18127.text: /_he will swallow up death forever./Then the Lord God will wipe away the tears from all faces,/_and the disgrace of his people he will take away from all the earth,/_for the Lord has spoken.

18128.text: /It will be said on that day,/_Lo, this is our God; we have waited for him, so that he might save us./_This is the Lord for whom we have waited;/_let us be glad and rejoice in his salvation.

18129.text: /For the hand of the Lord will rest on this mountain.¶The Moabites shall be trodden down in their place/_as straw is trodden down in a dung‑pit.

18130.text: /Though they spread out their hands in the midst of it,/_as swimmers spread out their hands to swim,/_their pride will be laid low despite the struggle of their hands.

18131.text: /The high fortifications of his walls will be brought down,/_laid low, cast to the ground, even to the dust.

18132.text: §¶On that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:/We have a strong city;/_he sets up victory/_like walls and bulwarks.

18133.text: /Open the gates,/_so that the righteous nation that keeps faith/_may enter in.

18134.text: /Those of steadfast mind you keep in peace—/_in peace because they trust in you.

18135.text: /Trust in the Lord forever,/_for in the Lord God/_you have an everlasting rock.

18136.text: /For he has brought low/_the inhabitants of the height;/_the lofty city he lays low./He lays it low to the ground,/_casts it to the dust.

18137.text: /The foot tramples it,/_the feet of the poor,/_the steps of the needy.

18138.text: ¶The way of the righteous is level;/_O Just One, you make smooth the path of the righteous.

18139.text: /In the path of your judgments,/_O Lord, we wait for you;/your name and your renown/_are the soul’s desire.

18140.text: /My soul yearns for you in the night,/_my spirit within me earnestly seeks you./For when your judgments are in the earth,/_the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness.

18141.text: /If favor is shown to the wicked,/_they do not learn righteousness;/in the land of uprightness they deal perversely/_and do not see the majesty of the Lord.

18142.text: /O Lord, your hand is lifted up,/_but they do not see it./Let them see your zeal for your people, and be ashamed./_Let the fire for your adversaries consume them.

18143.text: /O Lord, you will ordain peace for us,/_for indeed, all that we have done, you have done for us.

18144.text: /O Lord our God,/_other lords besides you have ruled over us,/_but we acknowledge your name alone.

18145.text: /The dead do not live;/_shades do not rise—/because you have punished and destroyed them,/_and wiped out all memory of them.

18146.text: /But you have increased the nation, O Lord,/_you have increased the nation; you are glorified;/_you have enlarged all the borders of the land.

18147.text: ¶O Lord, in distress they sought you,/_they poured out a prayer/_when your chastening was on them.

18148.text: /Like a woman with child,/_who writhes and cries out in her pangs/_when she is near her time,/so were we because of you, O Lord;

18149.text: /_we were with child, we writhed,/_but we gave birth only to wind./We have won no victories on earth,/_and no one is born to inhabit the world.

18150.text: /Your dead shall live, their corpses shall rise./_O dwellers in the dust, awake and sing for joy!/For your dew is a radiant dew,/_and the earth will give birth to those long dead.

18151.text: ¶Come, my people, enter your chambers,/_and shut your doors behind you;/hide yourselves for a little while/_until the wrath is past.

18152.text: /For the Lord comes out from his place/_to punish the inhabitants of the earth for their iniquity;/the earth will disclose the blood shed on it,/_and will no longer cover its slain.

18153.text: §¶On that day the Lord with his cruel and great and strong sword will punish Leviathan the fleeing serpent, Leviathan the twisting serpent, and he will kill the dragon that is in the sea.

18154.text: ¶On that day:/A pleasant vineyard, sing about it!

18155.text: /_I, the Lord, am its keeper;/_every moment I water it./I guard it night and day/_so that no one can harm it;

18156.text: /_I have no wrath./If it gives me thorns and briers,/_I will march to battle against it./_I will burn it up.

18157.text: /Or else let it cling to me for protection,/_let it make peace with me,/_let it make peace with me.

18158.text: ¶In days to come Jacob shall take root,/_Israel shall blossom and put forth shoots,/_and fill the whole world with fruit.

18159.text: ¶Has he struck them down as he struck down those who struck them?/_Or have they been killed as their killers were killed?

18160.text: /By expulsion, by exile you struggled against them;/_with his fierce blast he removed them in the day of the east wind.

18161.text: /Therefore by this the guilt of Jacob will be expiated,/_and this will be the full fruit of the removal of his sin:/when he makes all the stones of the altars/_like chalkstones crushed to pieces,/_no sacred poles or incense altars will remain standing.

18162.text: /For the fortified city is solitary,/_a habitation deserted and forsaken, like the wilderness;/the calves graze there,/_there they lie down, and strip its branches.

18163.text: /When its boughs are dry, they are broken;/_women come and make a fire of them./For this is a people without understanding;/_therefore he that made them will not have compassion on them,/_he that formed them will show them no favor.

18164.text: ¶On that day the Lord will thresh from the channel of the Euphrates to the Wadi of Egypt, and you will be gathered one by one, O people of Israel.

18165.text: And on that day a great trumpet will be blown, and those who were lost in the land of Assyria and those who were driven out to the land of Egypt will come and worship the Lord on the holy mountain at Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶Ah, the proud garland of the drunkards of Ephraim,/_and the fading flower of its glorious beauty,/_which is on the head of those bloated with rich food, of those overcome with wine!

18167.text: /See, the Lord has one who is mighty and strong;/_like a storm of hail, a destroying tempest,/like a storm of mighty, overflowing waters;/_with his hand he will hurl them down to the earth.

18168.text: /Trampled under foot will be/_the proud garland of the drunkards of Ephraim.

18169.text: /And the fading flower of its glorious beauty,/_which is on the head of those bloated with rich food,/will be like a first‑ripe fig before the summer;/_whoever sees it, eats it up/_as soon as it comes to hand.

18170.text: ¶In that day the Lord of hosts will be a garland of glory,/_and a diadem of beauty, to the remnant of his people;

18171.text: /and a spirit of justice to the one who sits in judgment,/_and strength to those who turn back the battle at the gate.

18172.text: ¶These also reel with wine/_and stagger with strong drink;/the priest and the prophet reel with strong drink,/_they are confused with wine,/_they stagger with strong drink;/they err in vision,/_they stumble in giving judgment.

18173.text: /All tables are covered with filthy vomit;/_no place is clean.

18174.text: ¶“Whom will he teach knowledge,/_and to whom will he explain the message?/Those who are weaned from milk,/_those taken from the breast?

17741.text: §¶Let me sing for my beloved¶▼my love‑song concerning his vineyard:/My beloved had a vineyard/_on a very fertile hill.

18175.text: /For it is precept upon precept, precept upon precept,/_line upon line, line upon line,/_here a little, there a little.”

17742.text: /He dug it and cleared it of stones,/_and planted it with choice vines;/he built a watchtower in the midst of it,/_and hewed out a wine vat in it;/he expected it to yield grapes,/_but it yielded wild grapes.

18176.text: ¶Truly, with stammering lip/_and with alien tongue/he will speak to this people,

17743.text: ¶And now, inhabitants of Jerusalem/_and people of Judah,/judge between me/_and my vineyard.

18177.text: /_to whom he has said,/“This is rest;/_give rest to the weary;/and this is repose”;/_yet they would not hear.

17744.text: /What more was there to do for my vineyard/_that I have not done in it?/When I expected it to yield grapes,/_why did it yield wild grapes?

18178.text: /Therefore the word of the Lord will be to them,/_“Precept upon precept, precept upon precept,/_line upon line, line upon line,/_here a little, there a little;”/in order that they may go, and fall backward,/_and be broken, and snared, and taken.

17745.text: ¶And now I will tell you/_what I will do to my vineyard./I will remove its hedge,/_and it shall be devoured;/I will break down its wall,/_and it shall be trampled down.

18179.text: ¶Therefore hear the word of the Lord, you scoffers/_who rule this people in Jerusalem.

17746.text: /I will make it a waste;/_it shall not be pruned or hoed,/_and it shall be overgrown with briers and thorns;/I will also command the clouds/_that they rain no rain upon it.

18180.text: /Because you have said, “We have made a covenant with death,/_and with Sheol we have an agreement;/when the overwhelming scourge passes through/_it will not come to us;/for we have made lies our refuge,/_and in falsehood we have taken shelter”;

17747.text: ¶For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts/_is the house of Israel,/and the people of Judah/_are his pleasant planting;/he expected justice,/_but saw bloodshed;/righteousness,/_but heard a cry!

18181.text: /therefore thus says the Lord God,/See, I am laying in Zion a foundation stone,/_a tested stone,/a precious cornerstone, a sure foundation:/_“One who trusts will not panic.”

17748.text: §¶Ah, you who join house to house,/_who add field to field,/until there is room for no one but you,/_and you are left to live alone/_in the midst of the land!

18182.text: /And I will make justice the line,/_and righteousness the plummet;/hail will sweep away the refuge of lies,/_and waters will overwhelm the shelter.

17749.text: /The Lord of hosts has sworn in my hearing:/Surely many houses shall be desolate,/_large and beautiful houses, without inhabitant.

18183.text: /Then your covenant with death will be annulled,/_and your agreement with Sheol will not stand;/when the overwhelming scourge passes through/_you will be beaten down by it.

17750.text: /For ten acres of vineyard shall yield but one bath,/_and a homer of seed shall yield a mere ephah.

18184.text: /As often as it passes through, it will take you;/_for morning by morning it will pass through,/_by day and by night;/and it will be sheer terror to understand the message.

17751.text: ¶Ah, you who rise early in the morning/_in pursuit of strong drink,/who linger in the evening/_to be inflamed by wine,

18185.text: /For the bed is too short to stretch oneself on it,/_and the covering too narrow to wrap oneself in it.

17752.text: /whose feasts consist of lyre and harp,/_tambourine and flute and wine,/but who do not regard the deeds of the Lord,/_or see the work of his hands!

18186.text: /For the Lord will rise up as on Mount Perazim,/_he will rage as in the valley of Gibeon/to do his deed—strange is his deed!—/_and to work his work—alien is his work!

18187.text: /Now therefore do not scoff,/_or your bonds will be made stronger;/for I have heard a decree of destruction/_from the Lord God of hosts upon the whole land.

17753.text: /Therefore my people go into exile without knowledge;/their nobles are dying of hunger,/_and their multitude is parched with thirst.

18188.text: ¶Listen, and hear my voice;/_Pay attention, and hear my speech.

17754.text: ¶Therefore Sheol has enlarged its appetite/_and opened its mouth beyond measure;/the nobility of Jerusalem and her multitude go down,/_her throng and all who exult in her.

18189.text: /Do those who plow for sowing plow continually?/_Do they continually open and harrow their ground?

17755.text: /People are bowed down, everyone is brought low,/_and the eyes of the haughty are humbled.

18190.text: /When they have leveled its surface,/_do they not scatter dill, sow cummin,/and plant wheat in rows/_and barley in its proper place,/_and spelt as the border?

17756.text: /But the Lord of hosts is exalted by justice,/_and the Holy God shows himself holy by righteousness.

18191.text: /For they are well instructed;/_their God teaches them.

17757.text: /Then the lambs shall graze as in their pasture,/_fatlings and kids shall feed among the ruins.

18192.text: ¶Dill is not threshed with a threshing sledge,/_nor is a cart wheel rolled over cummin;/but dill is beaten out with a stick,/_and cummin with a rod.

17758.text: ¶Ah, you who drag iniquity along with cords of falsehood,/_who drag sin along as with cart ropes,

18193.text: /Grain is crushed for bread,/_but one does not thresh it forever;/one drives the cart wheel and horses over it,/_but does not pulverize it.

17759.text: /who say, “Let him make haste,/_let him speed his work/_that we may see it;/let the plan of the Holy One of Israel hasten to fulfillment,/_that we may know it!”

18194.text: /This also comes from the Lord of hosts;/_he is wonderful in counsel,/_and excellent in wisdom.

17760.text: /Ah, you who call evil good/_and good evil,/who put darkness for light/_and light for darkness,/who put bitter for sweet/_and sweet for bitter!

17761.text: /Ah, you who are wise in your own eyes,/_and shrewd in your own sight!

18195.text: §¶Ah, Ariel, Ariel,/_the city where David encamped!/Add year to year;/_let the festivals run their round.

17762.text: /Ah, you who are heroes in drinking wine/_and valiant at mixing drink,

18196.text: /Yet I will distress Ariel,/_and there shall be moaning and lamentation,/_and Jerusalem shall be to me like an Ariel.

17763.text: /who acquit the guilty for a bribe,/_and deprive the innocent of their rights!

18197.text: /And like David I will encamp against you;/_I will besiege you with towers/_and raise siegeworks against you.

17764.text: §¶Therefore, as the tongue of fire devours the stubble,/_and as dry grass sinks down in the flame,/so their root will become rotten,/_and their blossom go up like dust;/for they have rejected the instruction of the Lord of hosts,/_and have despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.

18198.text: /Then deep from the earth you shall speak,/_from low in the dust your words shall come;/your voice shall come from the ground like the voice of a ghost,/_and your speech shall whisper out of the dust.

17765.text: ¶Therefore the anger of the Lord was kindled against his people,/_and he stretched out his hand against them and struck them;/_the mountains quaked,/and their corpses were like refuse/_in the streets./For all this his anger has not turned away,/_and his hand is stretched out still.

18199.text: ¶But the multitude of your foes shall be like small dust,/_and the multitude of tyrants like flying chaff./And in an instant, suddenly,

17766.text: ¶He will raise a signal for a nation far away,/_and whistle for a people at the ends of the earth;/Here they come, swiftly, speedily!

18200.text: /_you will be visited by the Lord of hosts/with thunder and earthquake and great noise,/_with whirlwind and tempest, and the flame of a devouring fire.

17767.text: /None of them is weary, none stumbles,/_none slumbers or sleeps,/not a loincloth is loose,/_not a sandal‑thong broken;

18201.text: /And the multitude of all the nations that fight against Ariel,/_all that fight against her and her stronghold, and who distress her,/_shall be like a dream, a vision of the night.

17768.text: /their arrows are sharp,/_all their bows bent,/their horses’ hoofs seem like flint,/_and their wheels like the whirlwind.

18202.text: /Just as when a hungry person dreams of eating/_and wakes up still hungry,/or a thirsty person dreams of drinking/_and wakes up faint, still thirsty,/so shall the multitude of all the nations be/_that fight against Mount Zion.

17769.text: /Their roaring is like a lion,/_like young lions they roar;/they growl and seize their prey,/_they carry it off, and no one can rescue.

18203.text: ¶Stupefy yourselves and be in a stupor,/_blind yourselves and be blind!/Be drunk, but not from wine;/_stagger, but not from strong drink!

17770.text: /They will roar over it on that day,/_like the roaring of the sea./And if one look to the land—/_only darkness and distress;/and the light grows dark with clouds.

18204.text: /For the Lord has poured out upon you/_a spirit of deep sleep;/he has closed your eyes, you prophets,/_and covered your heads, you seers.

17771.text: §¶In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and lofty; and the hem of his robe filled the temple.

18205.text: ¶The vision of all this has become for you like the words of a sealed document. If it is given to those who can read, with the command, “Read this,” they say, “We cannot, for it is sealed.”

17772.text: Seraphs were in attendance above him; each had six wings: with two they covered their faces, and with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.

18206.text: And if it is given to those who cannot read, saying, “Read this,” they say, “We cannot read.”

17773.text: And one called to another and said:¶▼“Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts;/the whole earth is full of his glory.”

18207.text: ¶The Lord said:/Because these people draw near with their mouths/_and honor me with their lips,/_while their hearts are far from me,/and their worship of me is a human commandment learned by rote;

17774.text: ¶The pivots on the thresholds shook at the voices of those who called, and the house filled with smoke.

18208.text: /so I will again do/_amazing things with this people,/_shocking and amazing./The wisdom of their wise shall perish,/_and the discernment of the discerning shall be hidden.

17775.text: And I said: “Woe is me! I am lost, for I am a man of unclean lips, and I live among a people of unclean lips; yet my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of hosts!”

18209.text: ¶Ha! You who hide a plan too deep for the Lord,/_whose deeds are in the dark,/_and who say, “Who sees us? Who knows us?”

17776.text: ¶Then one of the seraphs flew to me, holding a live coal that had been taken from the altar with a pair of tongs.

18210.text: /You turn things upside down!/_Shall the potter be regarded as the clay?/Shall the thing made say of its maker,/_“He did not make me”;/or the thing formed say of the one who formed it,/_“He has no understanding”?

17777.text: The seraph touched my mouth with it and said: “Now that this has touched your lips, your guilt has departed and your sin is blotted out.”

18211.text: §¶Shall not Lebanon in a very little while/_become a fruitful field,/_and the fruitful field be regarded as a forest?

17778.text: Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for us?” And I said, “Here am I; send me!”

18212.text: /On that day the deaf shall hear/_the words of a scroll,/and out of their gloom and darkness/_the eyes of the blind shall see.

17779.text: And he said, “Go and say to this people:¶▼‘Keep listening, but do not comprehend;/keep looking, but do not understand.’

18213.text: /The meek shall obtain fresh joy in the Lord,/_and the neediest people shall exult in the Holy One of Israel.

17780.text: /Make the mind of this people dull,/_and stop their ears,/_and shut their eyes,/so that they may not look with their eyes,/_and listen with their ears,/and comprehend with their minds,/_and turn and be healed.”

18214.text: /For the tyrant shall be no more,/_and the scoffer shall cease to be;/_all those alert to do evil shall be cut off—

17781.text: /Then I said, “How long, O Lord?” And he said:/“Until cities lie waste/_without inhabitant,/and houses without people,/_and the land is utterly desolate;

18215.text: /those who cause a person to lose a lawsuit,/_who set a trap for the arbiter in the gate,/_and without grounds deny justice to the one in the right.

17782.text: /until the Lord sends everyone far away,/_and vast is the emptiness in the midst of the land.

17783.text: /Even if a tenth part remain in it,/_it will be burned again,/like a terebinth or an oak/_whose stump remains standing/_when it is felled.”/The holy seed is its stump.

17784.text: §¶In the days of Ahaz son of Jotham son of Uzziah, king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel went up to attack Jerusalem, but could not mount an attack against it.

17785.text: When the house of David heard that Aram had allied itself with Ephraim, the heart of Ahaz and the heart of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake before the wind.

17786.text: ¶Then the Lord said to Isaiah, Go out to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear‑jashub, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the Fuller’s Field,

17787.text: and say to him, Take heed, be quiet, do not fear, and do not let your heart be faint because of these two smoldering stumps of firebrands, because of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah.

17788.text: Because Aram—with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah—has plotted evil against you, saying,

17789.text: Let us go up against Judah and cut off Jerusalem and conquer it for ourselves and make the son of Tabeel king in it;

17790.text: therefore thus says the Lord God:¶▼It shall not stand,/_and it shall not come to pass.

17791.text: /For the head of Aram is Damascus,/_and the head of Damascus is Rezin.¶►(Within sixty‑five years Ephraim will be shattered, no longer a people.)

17792.text: ¶The head of Ephraim is Samaria,/_and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah./If you do not stand firm in faith,/_you shall not stand at all.

17793.text: §¶Again the Lord spoke to Ahaz, saying,

17794.text: Ask a sign of the Lord your God; let it be deep as Sheol or high as heaven.

17795.text: But Ahaz said, I will not ask, and I will not put the Lord to the test.

17796.text: Then Isaiah said: “Hear then, O house of David! Is it too little for you to weary mortals, that you weary my God also?

17797.text: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Look, the young woman is with child and shall bear a son, and shall name him Immanuel.

17798.text: He shall eat curds and honey by the time he knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good.

17799.text: For before the child knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land before whose two kings you are in dread will be deserted.

17800.text: The Lord will bring on you and on your people and on your ancestral house such days as have not come since the day that Ephraim departed from Judah—the king of Assyria.”

17801.text: ¶On that day the Lord will whistle for the fly that is at the sources of the streams of Egypt, and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.

17802.text: And they will all come and settle in the steep ravines, and in the clefts of the rocks, and on all the thornbushes, and on all the pastures.

17803.text: ¶On that day the Lord will shave with a razor hired beyond the River—with the king of Assyria—the head and the hair of the feet, and it will take off the beard as well.

17804.text: ¶On that day one will keep alive a young cow and two sheep,

17805.text: and will eat curds because of the abundance of milk that they give; for everyone that is left in the land shall eat curds and honey.

17806.text: ¶On that day every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand shekels of silver, will become briers and thorns.

17807.text: With bow and arrows one will go there, for all the land will be briers and thorns;

17808.text: and as for all the hills that used to be hoed with a hoe, you will not go there for fear of briers and thorns; but they will become a place where cattle are let loose and where sheep tread.

17809.text: §¶Then the Lord said to me, Take a large tablet and write on it in common characters, “Belonging to Maher‑shalal‑hash‑baz,”

17810.text: and have it attested for me by reliable witnesses, the priest Uriah and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah.

17811.text: And I went to the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the Lord said to me, Name him Maher‑shalal‑hash‑baz;

17812.text: for before the child knows how to call “My father” or “My mother,” the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be carried away by the king of Assyria.

17814.text: Because this people has refused the waters of Shiloah that flow gently, and melt in fear before Rezin and the son of Remaliah;

17815.text: therefore, the Lord is bringing up against it the mighty flood waters of the River, the king of Assyria and all his glory; it will rise above all its channels and overflow all its banks;

17816.text: it will sweep on into Judah as a flood, and, pouring over, it will reach up to the neck; and its outspread wings will fill the breadth of your land, O Immanuel.

17817.text: ¶Band together, you peoples, and be dismayed;/_listen, all you far countries;/gird yourselves and be dismayed;/_gird yourselves and be dismayed!

17818.text: /Take counsel together, but it shall be brought to naught;/_speak a word, but it will not stand,/_for God is with us.

17819.text: ¶For the Lord spoke thus to me while his hand was strong upon me, and warned me not to walk in the way of this people, saying:

17820.text: Do not call conspiracy all that this people calls conspiracy, and do not fear what it fears, or be in dread.

17821.text: But the Lord of hosts, him you shall regard as holy; let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.

17822.text: He will become a sanctuary, a stone one strikes against; for both houses of Israel he will become a rock one stumbles over—a trap and a snare for the inhabitants of Jerusalem.

17823.text: And many among them shall stumble; they shall fall and be broken; they shall be snared and taken.

17824.text: §¶Bind up the testimony, seal the teaching among my disciples.

17825.text: I will wait for the Lord, who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in him.

17826.text: See, I and the children whom the Lord has given me are signs and portents in Israel from the Lord of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.

17827.text: Now if people say to you, “Consult the ghosts and the familiar spirits that chirp and mutter; should not a people consult their gods, the dead on behalf of the living,

17828.text: for teaching and for instruction?” surely, those who speak like this will have no dawn!

17829.text: They will pass through the land, greatly distressed and hungry; when they are hungry, they will be enraged and will curse their king and their gods. They will turn their faces upward,

17830.text: or they will look to the earth, but will see only distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish; and they will be thrust into thick darkness.

17831.text: §¶But there will be no gloom for those who were in anguish. In the former time he brought into contempt the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the latter time he will make glorious the way of the sea, the land beyond the Jordan, Galilee of the nations.

17832.text: ¶The people who walked in darkness/_have seen a great light;/those who lived in a land of deep darkness—/_on them light has shined.

17833.text: /You have multiplied the nation,/_you have increased its joy;/they rejoice before you/_as with joy at the harvest,/_as people exult when dividing plunder.

17834.text: /For the yoke of their burden,/_and the bar across their shoulders,/_the rod of their oppressor,/_you have broken as on the day of Midian.

17835.text: /For all the boots of the tramping warriors/_and all the garments rolled in blood/_shall be burned as fuel for the fire.

17836.text: /For a child has been born for us,/_a son given to us;/authority rests upon his shoulders;/_and he is named/Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,/_Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.

17837.text: /His authority shall grow continually,/_and there shall be endless peace/for the throne of David and his kingdom./_He will establish and uphold it/with justice and with righteousness/_from this time onward and forevermore./The zeal of the Lord of hosts will do this.

17838.text: §¶The Lord sent a word against Jacob,/_and it fell on Israel;

17839.text: /and all the people knew it—/_Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria—/_but in pride and arrogance of heart they said:

17840.text: /“The bricks have fallen,/_but we will build with dressed stones;/the sycamores have been cut down,/_but we will put cedars in their place.”

17841.text: /So the Lord raised adversaries against them,/_and stirred up their enemies,

17842.text: /the Arameans on the east and the Philistines on the west,/_and they devoured Israel with open mouth./For all this his anger has not turned away;/_his hand is stretched out still.

17843.text: ¶The people did not turn to him who struck them,/_or seek the Lord of hosts.

17844.text: /So the Lord cut off from Israel head and tail,/_palm branch and reed in one day—

17845.text: /elders and dignitaries are the head,/_and prophets who teach lies are the tail;

17846.text: /for those who led this people led them astray,/_and those who were led by them were left in confusion.

17847.text: /That is why the Lord did not have pity on their young people,/_or compassion on their orphans and widows;/for everyone was godless and an evildoer,/_and every mouth spoke folly./For all this his anger has not turned away;/_his hand is stretched out still.

17848.text: ¶For wickedness burned like a fire,/_consuming briers and thorns;/it kindled the thickets of the forest,/_and they swirled upward in a column of smoke.

17849.text: /Through the wrath of the Lord of hosts/_the land was burned,/and the people became like fuel for the fire;/_no one spared another.

17850.text: /They gorged on the right, but still were hungry,/_and they devoured on the left, but were not satisfied;/they devoured the flesh of their own kindred;

17851.text: /Manasseh devoured Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh,/_and together they were against Judah./For all this his anger has not turned away;/_his hand is stretched out still.

17852.text: ¶Ah, you who make iniquitous decrees,/_who write oppressive statutes,

17853.text: /to turn aside the needy from justice/_and to rob the poor of my people of their right,/that widows may be your spoil,/_and that you may make the orphans your prey!

17854.text: /What will you do on the day of punishment,/_in the calamity that will come from far away?/To whom will you flee for help,/_and where will you leave your wealth,

17855.text: /so as not to crouch among the prisoners/_or fall among the slain?/For all this his anger has not turned away;/_his hand is stretched out still.

17856.text: §¶Ah, Assyria, the rod of my anger—/_the club in their hands is my fury!

17857.text: /Against a godless nation I send him,/_and against the people of my wrath I command him,/to take spoil and seize plunder,/_and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.

17858.text: /But this is not what he intends,/_nor does he have this in mind;/but it is in his heart to destroy,/_and to cut off nations not a few.

17859.text: /For he says:/“Are not my commanders all kings?

17860.text: /Is not Calno like Carchemish?/_Is not Hamath like Arpad?/_Is not Samaria like Damascus?

17861.text: /As my hand has reached to the kingdoms of the idols/_whose images were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samaria,

17862.text: /shall I not do to Jerusalem and her idols/_what I have done to Samaria and her images?”

17863.text: ¶When the Lord has finished all his work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, he will punish the arrogant boasting of the king of Assyria and his haughty pride.

17864.text: For he says:¶▼“By the strength of my hand I have done it,/_and by my wisdom, for I have understanding;/I have removed the boundaries of peoples,/_and have plundered their treasures;/_like a bull I have brought down those who sat on thrones.

17865.text: /My hand has found, like a nest,/_the wealth of the peoples;/and as one gathers eggs that have been forsaken,/_so I have gathered all the earth;/and there was none that moved a wing,/_or opened its mouth, or chirped.”

17866.text: ¶Shall the ax vaunt itself over the one who wields it,/_or the saw magnify itself against the one who handles it?/As if a rod should raise the one who lifts it up,/_or as if a staff should lift the one who is not wood!

17867.text: /Therefore the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts,/_will send wasting sickness among his stout warriors,/and under his glory a burning will be kindled,/_like the burning of fire.

17868.text: /The light of Israel will become a fire,/_and his Holy One a flame;/and it will burn and devour/_his thorns and briers in one day.

17869.text: /The glory of his forest and his fruitful land/_the Lord will destroy, both soul and body,/_and it will be as when an invalid wastes away.

17870.text: /The remnant of the trees of his forest will be so few/_that a child can write them down.

17871.text: §¶On that day the remnant of Israel and the survivors of the house of Jacob will no more lean on the one who struck them, but will lean on the Lord, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.

17872.text: A remnant will return, the remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.

17873.text: For though your people Israel were like the sand of the sea, only a remnant of them will return. Destruction is decreed, overflowing with righteousness.

17874.text: For the Lord God of hosts will make a full end, as decreed, in all the earth.

17875.text: ¶Therefore thus says the Lord God of hosts: O my people, who live in Zion, do not be afraid of the Assyrians when they beat you with a rod and lift up their staff against you as the Egyptians did.

17876.text: For in a very little while my indignation will come to an end, and my anger will be directed to their destruction.

17877.text: The Lord of hosts will wield a whip against them, as when he struck Midian at the rock of Oreb; his staff will be over the sea, and he will lift it as he did in Egypt.

17878.text: On that day his burden will be removed from your shoulder, and his yoke will be destroyed from your neck.¶▼He has gone up from Rimmon,

17879.text: /_he has come to Aiath;/he has passed through Migron,/_at Michmash he stores his baggage;

17880.text: /they have crossed over the pass,/_at Geba they lodge for the night;/Ramah trembles,/_Gibeah of Saul has fled.

17881.text: /Cry aloud, O daughter Gallim!/_Listen, O Laishah!/_Answer her, O Anathoth!

17882.text: /Madmenah is in flight,/_the inhabitants of Gebim flee for safety.

17883.text: /This very day he will halt at Nob,/_he will shake his fist/_at the mount of daughter Zion,/_the hill of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶Look, the Sovereign, the Lord of hosts,/_will lop the boughs with terrifying power;/the tallest trees will be cut down,/_and the lofty will be brought low.

17885.text: /He will hack down the thickets of the forest with an ax,/_and Lebanon with its majestic trees will fall.

17886.text: §¶A shoot shall come out from the stump of Jesse,/_and a branch shall grow out of his roots.

17887.text: /The spirit of the Lord shall rest on him,/_the spirit of wisdom and understanding,/_the spirit of counsel and might,/_the spirit of knowledge and the fear of the Lord.

17888.text: /His delight shall be in the fear of the Lord.¶He shall not judge by what his eyes see,/_or decide by what his ears hear;

17889.text: /but with righteousness he shall judge the poor,/_and decide with equity for the meek of the earth;/he shall strike the earth with the rod of his mouth,/_and with the breath of his lips he shall kill the wicked.

17890.text: /Righteousness shall be the belt around his waist,/_and faithfulness the belt around his loins.

17891.text: ¶The wolf shall live with the lamb,/_the leopard shall lie down with the kid,/the calf and the lion and the fatling together,/_and a little child shall lead them.
