17892.text: /The cow and the bear shall graze,/_their young shall lie down together;/_and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.

17893.text: /The nursing child shall play over the hole of the asp,/_and the weaned child shall put its hand on the adder’s den.

17894.text: /They will not hurt or destroy/_on all my holy mountain;/for the earth will be full of the knowledge of the Lord/_as the waters cover the sea.

17895.text: §¶On that day the root of Jesse shall stand as a signal to the peoples; the nations shall inquire of him, and his dwelling shall be glorious.

17896.text: ¶On that day the Lord will extend his hand yet a second time to recover the remnant that is left of his people, from Assyria, from Egypt, from Pathros, from Ethiopia, from Elam, from Shinar, from Hamath, and from the coastlands of the sea.

17897.text: ¶He will raise a signal for the nations,/_and will assemble the outcasts of Israel,/and gather the dispersed of Judah/_from the four corners of the earth.

17898.text: /The jealousy of Ephraim shall depart,/_the hostility of Judah shall be cut off;/Ephraim shall not be jealous of Judah,/_and Judah shall not be hostile towards Ephraim.

17899.text: /But they shall swoop down on the backs of the Philistines in the west,/_together they shall plunder the people of the east./They shall put forth their hand against Edom and Moab,/_and the Ammonites shall obey them.

17900.text: /And the Lord will utterly destroy/_the tongue of the sea of Egypt;/and will wave his hand over the River/_with his scorching wind;/and will split it into seven channels,/_and make a way to cross on foot;

17901.text: /so there shall be a highway from Assyria/_for the remnant that is left of his people,/as there was for Israel/_when they came up from the land of Egypt.

17902.text: §¶You will say in that day:/I will give thanks to you, O Lord,/_for though you were angry with me,/your anger turned away,/_and you comforted me.

17903.text: ¶Surely God is my salvation;/_I will trust, and will not be afraid,/for the Lord God is my strength and my might;/_he has become my salvation.

17904.text: ¶With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation.

17905.text: And you will say in that day:¶▼Give thanks to the Lord,/_call on his name;/make known his deeds among the nations;/_proclaim that his name is exalted.

17906.text: ¶Sing praises to the Lord, for he has done gloriously;/_let this be known in all the earth.

17907.text: /Shout aloud and sing for joy, O royal Zion,/_for great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.

17908.text: §¶The oracle concerning Babylon that Isaiah son of Amoz saw.

17909.text: ¶On a bare hill raise a signal,/_cry aloud to them;/wave the hand for them to enter/_the gates of the nobles.

17910.text: /I myself have commanded my consecrated ones,/_have summoned my warriors, my proudly exulting ones,/_to execute my anger.

17911.text: ¶Listen, a tumult on the mountains/_as of a great multitude!/Listen, an uproar of kingdoms,/_of nations gathering together!/The Lord of hosts is mustering/_an army for battle.

18241.text: ¶He will give rain for the seed with which you sow the ground, and grain, the produce of the ground, which will be rich and plenteous. On that day your cattle will graze in broad pastures;

18242.text: and the oxen and donkeys that till the ground will eat silage, which has been winnowed with shovel and fork.

18243.text: On every lofty mountain and every high hill there will be brooks running with water—on a day of the great slaughter, when the towers fall.

18244.text: Moreover the light of the moon will be like the light of the sun, and the light of the sun will be sevenfold, like the light of seven days, on the day when the Lord binds up the injuries of his people, and heals the wounds inflicted by his blow.

18245.text: §¶See, the name of the Lord comes from far away,/_burning with his anger, and in thick rising smoke;/his lips are full of indignation,/_and his tongue is like a devouring fire;

18246.text: /his breath is like an overflowing stream/_that reaches up to the neck—/to sift the nations with the sieve of destruction,/_and to place on the jaws of the peoples a bridle that leads them astray.

18247.text: ¶You shall have a song as in the night when a holy festival is kept; and gladness of heart, as when one sets out to the sound of the flute to go to the mountain of the Lord, to the Rock of Israel.

18248.text: And the Lord will cause his majestic voice to be heard and the descending blow of his arm to be seen, in furious anger and a flame of devouring fire, with a cloudburst and tempest and hailstones.

18249.text: The Assyrian will be terror‐stricken at the voice of the Lord, when he strikes with his rod.

18250.text: And every stroke of the staff of punishment that the Lord lays upon him will be to the sound of timbrels and lyres; battling with brandished arm he will fight with him.

18251.text: For his burning place has long been prepared; truly it is made ready for the king, its pyre made deep and wide, with fire and wood in abundance; the breath of the Lord, like a stream of sulfur, kindles it.

18252.text: §¶Alas for those who go down to Egypt for help/_and who rely on horses,/who trust in chariots because they are many/_and in horsemen because they are very strong,/but do not look to the Holy One of Israel/_or consult the Lord!

18253.text: /Yet he too is wise and brings disaster;/_he does not call back his words,/but will rise against the house of the evildoers,/_and against the helpers of those who work iniquity.

18254.text: /The Egyptians are human, and not God;/_their horses are flesh, and not spirit./When the Lord stretches out his hand,/_the helper will stumble, and the one helped will fall,/_and they will all perish together.

18255.text: ¶For thus the Lord said to me,/As a lion or a young lion growls over its prey,/_and—when a band of shepherds is called out against it—/is not terrified by their shouting/_or daunted at their noise,/so the Lord of hosts will come down/_to fight upon Mount Zion and upon its hill.

18256.text: /Like birds hovering overhead, so the Lord of hosts/_will protect Jerusalem;/he will protect and deliver it,/_he will spare and rescue it.

18257.text: ¶Turn back to him whom you have deeply betrayed, O people of Israel.

18258.text: For on that day all of you shall throw away your idols of silver and idols of gold, which your hands have sinfully made for you.

18259.text: ¶“Then the Assyrian shall fall by a sword, not of mortals;/_and a sword, not of humans, shall devour him;/he shall flee from the sword,/_and his young men shall be put to forced labor.

18260.text: /His rock shall pass away in terror,/_and his officers desert the standard in panic,”/says the Lord, whose fire is in Zion,/_and whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶See, a king will reign in righteousness,/_and princes will rule with justice.

18262.text: /Each will be like a hiding place from the wind,/_a covert from the tempest,/like streams of water in a dry place,/_like the shade of a great rock in a weary land.

18263.text: /Then the eyes of those who have sight will not be closed,/_and the ears of those who have hearing will listen.

18264.text: /The minds of the rash will have good judgment,/_and the tongues of stammerers will speak readily and distinctly.

18265.text: /A fool will no longer be called noble,/_nor a villain said to be honorable.

18266.text: /For fools speak folly,/_and their minds plot iniquity:/to practice ungodliness,/_to utter error concerning the Lord,/to leave the craving of the hungry unsatisfied,/_and to deprive the thirsty of drink.

18267.text: /The villainies of villains are evil;/_they devise wicked devices/to ruin the poor with lying words,/_even when the plea of the needy is right.

18268.text: /But those who are noble plan noble things,/_and by noble things they stand.

18269.text: §¶Rise up, you women who are at ease, hear my voice;/_you complacent daughters, listen to my speech.

18270.text: /In little more than a year/_you will shudder, you complacent ones;/for the vintage will fail,/_the fruit harvest will not come.

18271.text: /Tremble, you women who are at ease,/_shudder, you complacent ones;/strip, and make yourselves bare,/_and put sackcloth on your loins.

18272.text: /Beat your breasts for the pleasant fields,/_for the fruitful vine,

18273.text: /for the soil of my people/_growing up in thorns and briers;/yes, for all the joyous houses/_in the jubilant city.

18274.text: /For the palace will be forsaken,/_the populous city deserted;/the hill and the watchtower/_will become dens forever,/the joy of wild asses,/_a pasture for flocks;

18275.text: /until a spirit from on high is poured out on us,/_and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field,/_and the fruitful field is deemed a forest.

18276.text: §¶Then justice will dwell in the wilderness,/_and righteousness abide in the fruitful field.

18277.text: /The effect of righteousness will be peace,/_and the result of righteousness, quietness and trust forever.

18278.text: /My people will abide in a peaceful habitation,/_in secure dwellings, and in quiet resting places.

18279.text: /The forest will disappear completely,/_and the city will be utterly laid low.

18280.text: /Happy will you be who sow beside every stream,/_who let the ox and the donkey range freely.

18281.text: §¶Ah, you destroyer,/_who yourself have not been destroyed;/you treacherous one,/_with whom no one has dealt treacherously!/When you have ceased to destroy,/_you will be destroyed;/and when you have stopped dealing treacherously,/_you will be dealt with treacherously.

18282.text: ¶O Lord, be gracious to us; we wait for you./_Be our arm every morning,/_our salvation in the time of trouble.

18283.text: /At the sound of tumult, peoples fled;/_before your majesty, nations scattered.

18284.text: /Spoil was gathered as the caterpillar gathers;/_as locusts leap, they leaped upon it.

18285.text: /The Lord is exalted, he dwells on high;/_he filled Zion with justice and righteousness;

18286.text: /he will be the stability of your times,/_abundance of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge;/_the fear of the Lord is Zion’s treasure.

18287.text: ¶Listen! the valiant cry in the streets;/_the envoys of peace weep bitterly.

18288.text: /The highways are deserted,/_travelers have quit the road./The treaty is broken,/_its oaths are despised,/_its obligation is disregarded.

18289.text: /The land mourns and languishes;/_Lebanon is confounded and withers away;/Sharon is like a desert;/_and Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves.

18290.text: ¶“Now I will arise,” says the Lord,/_“now I will lift myself up;/_now I will be exalted.

18291.text: /You conceive chaff, you bring forth stubble;/_your breath is a fire that will consume you.

18292.text: /And the peoples will be as if burned to lime,/_like thorns cut down, that are burned in the fire.”

18293.text: ¶Hear, you who are far away, what I have done;/_and you who are near, acknowledge my might.

18294.text: /The sinners in Zion are afraid;/_trembling has seized the godless:/“Who among us can live with the devouring fire?/_Who among us can live with everlasting flames?”

18295.text: /Those who walk righteously and speak uprightly,/_who despise the gain of oppression,/who wave away a bribe instead of accepting it,/_who stop their ears from hearing of bloodshed/_and shut their eyes from looking on evil,

18296.text: /they will live on the heights;/_their refuge will be the fortresses of rocks;/_their food will be supplied, their water assured.

18297.text: §¶Your eyes will see the king in his beauty;/_they will behold a land that stretches far away.

18298.text: /Your mind will muse on the terror:/_“Where is the one who counted?/_Where is the one who weighed the tribute?/_Where is the one who counted the towers?”

18299.text: /No longer will you see the insolent people,/_the people of an obscure speech that you cannot comprehend,/_stammering in a language that you cannot understand.

18300.text: /Look on Zion, the city of our appointed festivals!/_Your eyes will see Jerusalem,/_a quiet habitation, an immovable tent,/whose stakes will never be pulled up,/_and none of whose ropes will be broken.

18301.text: /But there the Lord in majesty will be for us/_a place of broad rivers and streams,/where no galley with oars can go,/_nor stately ship can pass.

18302.text: /For the Lord is our judge, the Lord is our ruler,/_the Lord is our king; he will save us.

18303.text: ¶Your rigging hangs loose;/_it cannot hold the mast firm in its place,/_or keep the sail spread out.¶Then prey and spoil in abundance will be divided;/_even the lame will fall to plundering.

18304.text: /And no inhabitant will say, “I am sick”;/_the people who live there will be forgiven their iniquity.

18305.text: §¶Draw near, O nations, to hear;/_O peoples, give heed!/Let the earth hear, and all that fills it;/_the world, and all that comes from it.

18306.text: /For the Lord is enraged against all the nations,/_and furious against all their hordes;/_he has doomed them, has given them over for slaughter.

18307.text: /Their slain shall be cast out,/_and the stench of their corpses shall rise;/_the mountains shall flow with their blood.

18308.text: /All the host of heaven shall rot away,/_and the skies roll up like a scroll./All their host shall wither/_like a leaf withering on a vine,/_or fruit withering on a fig tree.

18309.text: ¶When my sword has drunk its fill in the heavens,/_lo, it will descend upon Edom,/_upon the people I have doomed to judgment.

18310.text: /The Lord has a sword; it is sated with blood,/_it is gorged with fat,/_with the blood of lambs and goats,/_with the fat of the kidneys of rams./For the Lord has a sacrifice in Bozrah,/_a great slaughter in the land of Edom.

18311.text: /Wild oxen shall fall with them,/_and young steers with the mighty bulls./Their land shall be soaked with blood,/_and their soil made rich with fat.

18312.text: ¶For the Lord has a day of vengeance,/_a year of vindication by Zion’s cause.

18313.text: /And the streams of Edom shall be turned into pitch,/_and her soil into sulfur;/_her land shall become burning pitch.

18314.text: /Night and day it shall not be quenched;/_its smoke shall go up forever./From generation to generation it shall lie waste;/_no one shall pass through it forever and ever.

18315.text: /But the hawk and the hedgehog shall possess it;/_the owl and the raven shall live in it./He shall stretch the line of confusion over it,/_and the plummet of chaos over its nobles.

18316.text: /They shall name it No Kingdom There,/_and all its princes shall be nothing.

18317.text: /Thorns shall grow over its strongholds,/_nettles and thistles in its fortresses./It shall be the haunt of jackals,/_an abode for ostriches.

18318.text: /Wildcats shall meet with hyenas,/_goat‐demons shall call to each other;/there too Lilith shall repose,/_and find a place to rest.

18319.text: /There shall the owl nest/_and lay and hatch and brood in its shadow;/there too the buzzards shall gather,/_each one with its mate.

18320.text: /Seek and read from the book of the Lord:/_Not one of these shall be missing;/_none shall be without its mate./For the mouth of the Lord has commanded,/_and his spirit has gathered them.

18321.text: /He has cast the lot for them,/_his hand has portioned it out to them with the line;/they shall possess it forever,/_from generation to generation they shall live in it.

18322.text: §¶The wilderness and the dry land shall be glad,/_the desert shall rejoice and blossom;/like the crocus

18323.text: /it shall blossom abundantly,/_and rejoice with joy and singing./The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it,/_the majesty of Carmel and Sharon./They shall see the glory of the Lord,/_the majesty of our God.

18324.text: ¶Strengthen the weak hands,/_and make firm the feeble knees.

18325.text: /Say to those who are of a fearful heart,/_“Be strong, do not fear!/Here is your God./_He will come with vengeance,/with terrible recompense./_He will come and save you.”

18326.text: ¶Then the eyes of the blind shall be opened,/_and the ears of the deaf unstopped;

18327.text: /then the lame shall leap like a deer,/_and the tongue of the speechless sing for joy./For waters shall break forth in the wilderness,/_and streams in the desert;

18328.text: /the burning sand shall become a pool,/_and the thirsty ground springs of water;/the haunt of jackals shall become a swamp,/_the grass shall become reeds and rushes.

18329.text: ¶A highway shall be there,/_and it shall be called the Holy Way;/the unclean shall not travel on it,/_but it shall be for God’s people;/_no traveler, not even fools, shall go astray.

18330.text: /No lion shall be there,/_nor shall any ravenous beast come up on it;/they shall not be found there,/_but the redeemed shall walk there.

18331.text: /And the ransomed of the Lord shall return,/_and come to Zion with singing;/everlasting joy shall be upon their heads;/_they shall obtain joy and gladness,/_and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.

18332.text: §¶In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, King Sennacherib of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and captured them.

18333.text: The king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem, with a great army. He stood by the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the Fuller’s Field.

18334.text: And there came out to him Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder.

18335.text: ¶The Rabshakeh said to them, “Say to Hezekiah: Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you base this confidence of yours?

18336.text: Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? On whom do you now rely, that you have rebelled against me?

18337.text: See, you are relying on Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who rely on him.

18338.text: But if you say to me, ‘We rely on the Lord our God,’ is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, ‘You shall worship before this altar’?

18339.text: Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders on them.

18340.text: How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master’s servants, when you rely on Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?

18341.text: Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this land to destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this land, and destroy it.”

18342.text: ¶Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it; do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”

18343.text: But the Rabshakeh said, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you, and not to the people sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and drink their own urine?”

18344.text: ¶Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah, “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!

18345.text: Thus says the king: ‘Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you.

18346.text: Do not let Hezekiah make you rely on the Lord by saying, The Lord will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’

18347.text: Do not listen to Hezekiah; for thus says the king of Assyria: ‘Make your peace with me and come out to me; then every one of you will eat from your own vine and your own fig tree and drink water from your own cistern,

18348.text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards.

18349.text: Do not let Hezekiah mislead you by saying, The Lord will save us. Has any of the gods of the nations saved their land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?

18350.text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?

18351.text: Who among all the gods of these countries have saved their countries out of my hand, that the Lord should save Jerusalem out of my hand?’”

18352.text: ¶But they were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”

18353.text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn, and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.

18354.text: §¶When King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the Lord.

18355.text: And he sent Eliakim, who was in charge of the palace, and Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.

18356.text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah, This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; children have come to the birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.

18357.text: It may be that the Lord your God heard the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard; therefore lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.”

18358.text: ¶When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,

18359.text: Isaiah said to them, “Say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have reviled me.

18360.text: I myself will put a spirit in him, so that he shall hear a rumor, and return to his own land; I will cause him to fall by the sword in his own land.’”

18361.text: ¶The Rabshakeh returned, and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah; for he had heard that the king had left Lachish.

18362.text: Now the king heard concerning King Tirhakah of Ethiopia, “He has set out to fight against you.” When he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,

18363.text: “Thus shall you speak to King Hezekiah of Judah: Do not let your God on whom you rely deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.

18364.text: See, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands, destroying them utterly. Shall you be delivered?

18365.text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations that my predecessors destroyed, Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?

18366.text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, the king of Hena, or the king of Ivvah?”

18367.text: §¶Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers and read it; then Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord and spread it before the Lord.

18368.text: And Hezekiah prayed to the Lord, saying:

18369.text: “O Lord of hosts, God of Israel, who are enthroned above the cherubim, you are God, you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth; you have made heaven and earth.

18370.text: Incline your ear, O Lord, and hear; open your eyes, O Lord, and see; hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to mock the living God.

18371.text: Truly, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their lands,

18372.text: and have hurled their gods into the fire, though they were no gods, but the work of human hands—wood and stone—and so they were destroyed.

18373.text: So now, O Lord our God, save us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone are the Lord.”

18374.text: ¶Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent to Hezekiah, saying: “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Because you have prayed to me concerning King Sennacherib of Assyria,

18375.text: this is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him:¶▼She despises you, she scorns you—/_virgin daughter Zion;/she tosses her head—behind your back,/_daughter Jerusalem.

18376.text: ¶“Whom have you mocked and reviled?/_Against whom have you raised your voice/and haughtily lifted your eyes?/_Against the Holy One of Israel!

18377.text: /By your servants you have mocked the Lord,/_and you have said, ‘With my many chariots/I have gone up the heights of the mountains,/_to the far recesses of Lebanon;/I felled its tallest cedars,/_its choicest cypresses;/I came to its remotest height,/_its densest forest.

18378.text: /I dug wells/_and drank waters,/I dried up with the sole of my foot/_all the streams of Egypt.’

18379.text: ¶“Have you not heard/_that I determined it long ago?/I planned from days of old/_what now I bring to pass,/that you should make fortified cities/_crash into heaps of ruins,

18380.text: /while their inhabitants, shorn of strength,/_are dismayed and confounded;/they have become like plants of the field/_and like tender grass,/like grass on the housetops,/_blighted before it is grown.

18381.text: ¶“I know your rising up and your sitting down,/_your going out and coming in,/_and your raging against me.

18382.text: /Because you have raged against me/_and your arrogance has come to my ears,/I will put my hook in your nose/_and my bit in your mouth;/I will turn you back on the way/_by which you came.

18383.text: ¶“And this shall be the sign for you: This year eat what grows of itself, and in the second year what springs from that; then in the third year sow, reap, plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.

18384.text: The surviving remnant of the house of Judah shall again take root downward, and bear fruit upward;

18385.text: for from Jerusalem a remnant shall go out, and from Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will do this.

18386.text: ¶“Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not come into this city, shoot an arrow there, come before it with a shield, or cast up a siege ramp against it.

18387.text: By the way that he came, by the same he shall return; he shall not come into this city, says the Lord.

18388.text: For I will defend this city to save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.”

18389.text: §¶Then the angel of the Lord set out and struck down one hundred eighty‐five thousand in the camp of the Assyrians; when morning dawned, they were all dead bodies.

18390.text: Then King Sennacherib of Assyria left, went home, and lived at Nineveh.

18391.text: As he was worshiping in the house of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer killed him with the sword, and they escaped into the land of Ararat. His son Esar‐haddon succeeded him.

18392.text: §¶In those days Hezekiah became sick and was at the point of death. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came to him, and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die; you shall not recover.”

18393.text: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall, and prayed to the Lord:

18394.text: “Remember now, O Lord, I implore you, how I have walked before you in faithfulness with a whole heart, and have done what is good in your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.

18395.text: ¶Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah:

18396.text: “Go and say to Hezekiah, Thus says the Lord, the God of your ancestor David: I have heard your prayer, I have seen your tears; I will add fifteen years to your life.

18397.text: I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria, and defend this city.

18398.text: ¶“This is the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do this thing that he has promised:

18399.text: See, I will make the shadow cast by the declining sun on the dial of Ahaz turn back ten steps.” So the sun turned back on the dial the ten steps by which it had declined.

18400.text: ¶A writing of King Hezekiah of Judah, after he had been sick and had recovered from his sickness:

18401.text: ¶I said: In the noontide of my days/_I must depart;/I am consigned to the gates of Sheol/_for the rest of my years.

18402.text: /I said, I shall not see the Lord/_in the land of the living;/I shall look upon mortals no more/_among the inhabitants of the world.

18403.text: /My dwelling is plucked up and removed from me/_like a shepherd’s tent;/like a weaver I have rolled up my life;/_he cuts me off from the loom;/from day to night you bring me to an end;

18404.text: /_I cry for help until morning;/like a lion he breaks all my bones;/_from day to night you bring me to an end.

18405.text: ¶Like a swallow or a crane I clamor,/_I moan like a dove./My eyes are weary with looking upward./_O Lord, I am oppressed; be my security!

18406.text: /But what can I say? For he has spoken to me,/_and he himself has done it./All my sleep has fled/_because of the bitterness of my soul.

18407.text: ¶O Lord, by these things people live,/_and in all these is the life of my spirit./_Oh, restore me to health and make me live!

18408.text: /Surely it was for my welfare/_that I had great bitterness;/but you have held back my life/_from the pit of destruction,/for you have cast all my sins/_behind your back.

18409.text: /For Sheol cannot thank you,/_death cannot praise you;/those who go down to the Pit cannot hope/_for your faithfulness.

18410.text: /The living, the living, they thank you,/_as I do this day;/fathers make known to children/_your faithfulness.

18411.text: ¶The Lord will save me,/_and we will sing to stringed instruments/all the days of our lives,/_at the house of the Lord.

18412.text: ¶Now Isaiah had said, “Let them take a lump of figs, and apply it to the boil, so that he may recover.”

18413.text: Hezekiah also had said, “What is the sign that I shall go up to the house of the Lord?”

18414.text: §¶At that time King Merodach‐baladan son of Baladan of Babylon sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he heard that he had been sick and had recovered.

18415.text: Hezekiah welcomed them; he showed them his treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oil, his whole armory, all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.

18416.text: Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and said to him, “What did these men say? From where did they come to you?” Hezekiah answered, “They have come to me from a far country, from Babylon.”

18417.text: He said, “What have they seen in your house?” Hezekiah answered, “They have seen all that is in my house; there is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”

18418.text: ¶Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord of hosts:

18419.text: Days are coming when all that is in your house, and that which your ancestors have stored up until this day, shall be carried to Babylon; nothing shall be left, says the Lord.

18420.text: Some of your own sons who are born to you shall be taken away; they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

18421.text: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “There will be peace and security in my days.”

18422.text: §¶Comfort, O comfort my people,/_says your God.

18423.text: /Speak tenderly to Jerusalem,/_and cry to her/that she has served her term,/_that her penalty is paid,/that she has received from the Lord’s hand/_double for all her sins.

18424.text: ¶A voice cries out:/“In the wilderness prepare the way of the Lord,/_make straight in the desert a highway for our God.

18425.text: /Every valley shall be lifted up,/_and every mountain and hill be made low;/the uneven ground shall become level,/_and the rough places a plain.

18426.text: /Then the glory of the Lord shall be revealed,/_and all people shall see it together,/_for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

18427.text: ¶A voice says, “Cry out!”/_And I said, “What shall I cry?”/All people are grass,/_their constancy is like the flower of the field.

18428.text: /The grass withers, the flower fades,/_when the breath of the Lord blows upon it;/_surely the people are grass.

18429.text: /The grass withers, the flower fades;/_but the word of our God will stand forever.

18430.text: /Get you up to a high mountain,/_O Zion, herald of good tidings;/lift up your voice with strength,/_O Jerusalem, herald of good tidings,/_lift it up, do not fear;/say to the cities of Judah,/_“Here is your God!”

18431.text: /See, the Lord God comes with might,/_and his arm rules for him;/his reward is with him,/_and his recompense before him.

18432.text: /He will feed his flock like a shepherd;/_he will gather the lambs in his arms,/and carry them in his bosom,/_and gently lead the mother sheep.

18433.text: ¶Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand/_and marked off the heavens with a span,/enclosed the dust of the earth in a measure,/_and weighed the mountains in scales/_and the hills in a balance?

18434.text: /Who has directed the spirit of the Lord,/_or as his counselor has instructed him?

18435.text: /Whom did he consult for his enlightenment,/_and who taught him the path of justice?/Who taught him knowledge,/_and showed him the way of understanding?

18436.text: /Even the nations are like a drop from a bucket,/_and are accounted as dust on the scales;/_see, he takes up the isles like fine dust.

18437.text: /Lebanon would not provide fuel enough,/_nor are its animals enough for a burnt offering.

18438.text: /All the nations are as nothing before him;/_they are accounted by him as less than nothing and emptiness.

18439.text: ¶To whom then will you liken God,/_or what likeness compare with him?

18440.text: /An idol? —A workman casts it,/_and a goldsmith overlays it with gold,/_and casts for it silver chains.

18441.text: /As a gift one chooses mulberry wood/_—wood that will not rot—/then seeks out a skilled artisan/_to set up an image that will not topple.

18442.text: ¶Have you not known? Have you not heard?/_Has it not been told you from the beginning?/_Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?

18443.text: /It is he who sits above the circle of the earth,/_and its inhabitants are like grasshoppers;/who stretches out the heavens like a curtain,/_and spreads them like a tent to live in;

18444.text: /who brings princes to naught,/_and makes the rulers of the earth as nothing.

18445.text: ¶Scarcely are they planted, scarcely sown,/_scarcely has their stem taken root in the earth,/when he blows upon them, and they wither,/_and the tempest carries them off like stubble.

18446.text: ¶To whom then will you compare me,/_or who is my equal? says the Holy One.

18447.text: /Lift up your eyes on high and see:/_Who created these?/He who brings out their host and numbers them,/_calling them all by name;/because he is great in strength,/_mighty in power,/_not one is missing.

18448.text: ¶Why do you say, O Jacob,/_and speak, O Israel,/“My way is hidden from the Lord,/_and my right is disregarded by my God”?

18449.text: /Have you not known? Have you not heard?/The Lord is the everlasting God,/_the Creator of the ends of the earth./He does not faint or grow weary;/_his understanding is unsearchable.

18450.text: /He gives power to the faint,/_and strengthens the powerless.

18451.text: /Even youths will faint and be weary,/_and the young will fall exhausted;

18452.text: /but those who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength,/_they shall mount up with wings like eagles,/they shall run and not be weary,/_they shall walk and not faint.

18453.text: §¶Listen to me in silence, O coastlands;/_let the peoples renew their strength;/let them approach, then let them speak;/_let us together draw near for judgment.

18454.text: ¶Who has roused a victor from the east,/_summoned him to his service?/He delivers up nations to him,/_and tramples kings under foot;/he makes them like dust with his sword,/_like driven stubble with his bow.

18455.text: /He pursues them and passes on safely,/_scarcely touching the path with his feet.

18456.text: /Who has performed and done this,/_calling the generations from the beginning?/I, the Lord, am first,/_and will be with the last.

18457.text: /The coastlands have seen and are afraid,/_the ends of the earth tremble;/_they have drawn near and come.

18458.text: /Each one helps the other,/_saying to one another, “Take courage!”

18459.text: /The artisan encourages the goldsmith,/_and the one who smooths with the hammer encourages the one who strikes the anvil,/saying of the soldering, “It is good”;/_and they fasten it with nails so that it cannot be moved.

18460.text: /But you, Israel, my servant,/_Jacob, whom I have chosen,/_the offspring of Abraham, my friend;

18461.text: /you whom I took from the ends of the earth,/_and called from its farthest corners,/saying to you, “You are my servant,/_I have chosen you and not cast you off”;

18462.text: /do not fear, for I am with you,/_do not be afraid, for I am your God;/I will strengthen you, I will help you,/_I will uphold you with my victorious right hand.

18463.text: ¶Yes, all who are incensed against you/_shall be ashamed and disgraced;/those who strive against you/_shall be as nothing and shall perish.

18464.text: /You shall seek those who contend with you,/_but you shall not find them;/those who war against you/_shall be as nothing at all.

18465.text: /For I, the Lord your God,/_hold your right hand;/it is I who say to you, “Do not fear,/_I will help you.”

18466.text: ¶Do not fear, you worm Jacob,/_you insect Israel!/I will help you, says the Lord;/_your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel.

18467.text: /Now, I will make of you a threshing sledge,/_sharp, new, and having teeth;/you shall thresh the mountains and crush them,/_and you shall make the hills like chaff.

18468.text: /You shall winnow them and the wind shall carry them away,/_and the tempest shall scatter them./Then you shall rejoice in the Lord;/_in the Holy One of Israel you shall glory.

18469.text: ¶When the poor and needy seek water,/_and there is none,/_and their tongue is parched with thirst,/I the Lord will answer them,/_I the God of Israel will not forsake them.

18470.text: /I will open rivers on the bare heights,/_and fountains in the midst of the valleys;/I will make the wilderness a pool of water,/_and the dry land springs of water.

18471.text: /I will put in the wilderness the cedar,/_the acacia, the myrtle, and the olive;/I will set in the desert the cypress,/_the plane and the pine together,

18472.text: /so that all may see and know,/_all may consider and understand,/that the hand of the Lord has done this,/_the Holy One of Israel has created it.

18473.text: §¶Set forth your case, says the Lord;/_bring your proofs, says the King of Jacob.

18474.text: /Let them bring them, and tell us/_what is to happen./Tell us the former things, what they are,/_so that we may consider them,/and that we may know their outcome;/_or declare to us the things to come.

18475.text: /Tell us what is to come hereafter,/_that we may know that you are gods;/do good, or do harm,/_that we may be afraid and terrified.

18476.text: /You, indeed, are nothing/_and your work is nothing at all;/_whoever chooses you is an abomination.

18477.text: ¶I stirred up one from the north, and he has come,/_from the rising of the sun he was summoned by name./He shall trample on rulers as on mortar,/_as the potter treads clay.

18478.text: /Who declared it from the beginning, so that we might know,/_and beforehand, so that we might say, “He is right”?/There was no one who declared it, none who proclaimed,/_none who heard your words.

18479.text: /I first have declared it to Zion,/_and I give to Jerusalem a herald of good tidings.

18480.text: /But when I look there is no one;/_among these there is no counselor/_who, when I ask, gives an answer.

18481.text: /No, they are all a delusion;/_their works are nothing;/_their images are empty wind.

18482.text: §¶Here is my servant, whom I uphold,/_my chosen, in whom my soul delights;/I have put my spirit upon him;/_he will bring forth justice to the nations.

18483.text: /He will not cry or lift up his voice,/_or make it heard in the street;

18484.text: /a bruised reed he will not break,/_and a dimly burning wick he will not quench;/_he will faithfully bring forth justice.

18485.text: /He will not grow faint or be crushed/_until he has established justice in the earth;/_and the coastlands wait for his teaching.

18486.text: ¶Thus says God, the Lord,/_who created the heavens and stretched them out,/_who spread out the earth and what comes from it,/who gives breath to the people upon it/_and spirit to those who walk in it:

18487.text: /I am the Lord, I have called you in righteousness,/_I have taken you by the hand and kept you;/I have given you as a covenant to the people,/_a light to the nations,

18488.text: /_to open the eyes that are blind,/to bring out the prisoners from the dungeon,/_from the prison those who sit in darkness.

18489.text: /I am the Lord, that is my name;/_my glory I give to no other,/_nor my praise to idols.

18490.text: /See, the former things have come to pass,/_and new things I now declare;/before they spring forth,/_I tell you of them.

18491.text: §¶Sing to the Lord a new song,/_his praise from the end of the earth!/Let the sea roar and all that fills it,/_the coastlands and their inhabitants.

18492.text: /Let the desert and its towns lift up their voice,/_the villages that Kedar inhabits;/let the inhabitants of Sela sing for joy,/_let them shout from the tops of the mountains.

18493.text: /Let them give glory to the Lord,/_and declare his praise in the coastlands.

18494.text: /The Lord goes forth like a soldier,/_like a warrior he stirs up his fury;/he cries out, he shouts aloud,/_he shows himself mighty against his foes.

18495.text: ¶For a long time I have held my peace,/_I have kept still and restrained myself;/now I will cry out like a woman in labor,/_I will gasp and pant.

18496.text: /I will lay waste mountains and hills,/_and dry up all their herbage;/I will turn the rivers into islands,/_and dry up the pools.

18497.text: /I will lead the blind/_by a road they do not know,/by paths they have not known/_I will guide them./I will turn the darkness before them into light,/_the rough places into level ground./These are the things I will do,/_and I will not forsake them.

18498.text: /They shall be turned back and utterly put to shame—/_those who trust in carved images,/who say to cast images,/_“You are our gods.”

18499.text: ¶Listen, you that are deaf;/_and you that are blind, look up and see!

18500.text: /Who is blind but my servant,/_or deaf like my messenger whom I send?/Who is blind like my dedicated one,/_or blind like the servant of the Lord?

18501.text: /He sees many things, but does not observe them;/_his ears are open, but he does not hear.

18502.text: §¶The Lord was pleased, for the sake of his righteousness,/_to magnify his teaching and make it glorious.

18503.text: /But this is a people robbed and plundered,/_all of them are trapped in holes/_and hidden in prisons;/they have become a prey with no one to rescue,/_a spoil with no one to say, “Restore!”

18504.text: /Who among you will give heed to this,/_who will attend and listen for the time to come?

18505.text: /Who gave up Jacob to the spoiler,/_and Israel to the robbers?/Was it not the Lord, against whom we have sinned,/_in whose ways they would not walk,/_and whose law they would not obey?

18506.text: /So he poured upon him the heat of his anger/_and the fury of war;/it set him on fire all around, but he did not understand;/_it burned him, but he did not take it to heart.

18507.text: §¶But now thus says the Lord,/_he who created you, O Jacob,/_he who formed you, O Israel:/Do not fear, for I have redeemed you;/_I have called you by name, you are mine.

18508.text: /When you pass through the waters, I will be with you;/_and through the rivers, they shall not overwhelm you;/when you walk through fire you shall not be burned,/_and the flame shall not consume you.

18509.text: /For I am the Lord your God,/_the Holy One of Israel, your Savior./I give Egypt as your ransom,/_Ethiopia and Seba in exchange for you.

18510.text: /Because you are precious in my sight,/_and honored, and I love you,/I give people in return for you,/_nations in exchange for your life.

18511.text: /Do not fear, for I am with you;/_I will bring your offspring from the east,/_and from the west I will gather you;

18512.text: /I will say to the north, “Give them up,”/_and to the south, “Do not withhold;/bring my sons from far away/_and my daughters from the end of the earth—

18513.text: /everyone who is called by my name,/_whom I created for my glory,/_whom I formed and made.”

18514.text: ¶Bring forth the people who are blind, yet have eyes,/_who are deaf, yet have ears!

18515.text: /Let all the nations gather together,/_and let the peoples assemble./Who among them declared this,/_and foretold to us the former things?/Let them bring their witnesses to justify them,/_and let them hear and say, “It is true.”

18516.text: /You are my witnesses, says the Lord,/_and my servant whom I have chosen,/so that you may know and believe me/_and understand that I am he./Before me no god was formed,/_nor shall there be any after me.

18517.text: /I, I am the Lord,/_and besides me there is no savior.

18518.text: /I declared and saved and proclaimed,/_when there was no strange god among you;/_and you are my witnesses, says the Lord.

18519.text: /I am God, and also henceforth I am He;/_there is no one who can deliver from my hand;/_I work and who can hinder it?

18520.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/For your sake I will send to Babylon/_and break down all the bars,/_and the shouting of the Chaldeans will be turned to lamentation.

18521.text: /I am the Lord, your Holy One,/_the Creator of Israel, your King.

18522.text: /Thus says the Lord,/_who makes a way in the sea,/_a path in the mighty waters,

18523.text: /who brings out chariot and horse,/_army and warrior;/they lie down, they cannot rise,/_they are extinguished, quenched like a wick:

18524.text: /Do not remember the former things,/_or consider the things of old.

18525.text: /I am about to do a new thing;/_now it springs forth, do you not perceive it?/I will make a way in the wilderness/_and rivers in the desert.

18526.text: /The wild animals will honor me,/_the jackals and the ostriches;/for I give water in the wilderness,/_rivers in the desert,/to give drink to my chosen people,

18527.text: /_the people whom I formed for myself/so that they might declare my praise.

18528.text: ¶Yet you did not call upon me, O Jacob;/_but you have been weary of me, O Israel!

18529.text: /You have not brought me your sheep for burnt offerings,/_or honored me with your sacrifices./I have not burdened you with offerings,/_or wearied you with frankincense.

18530.text: /You have not bought me sweet cane with money,/_or satisfied me with the fat of your sacrifices./But you have burdened me with your sins;/_you have wearied me with your iniquities.

18531.text: ¶I, I am He/_who blots out your transgressions for my own sake,/_and I will not remember your sins.

18532.text: /Accuse me, let us go to trial;/_set forth your case, so that you may be proved right.

18533.text: /Your first ancestor sinned,/_and your interpreters transgressed against me.

18534.text: /Therefore I profaned the princes of the sanctuary,/_I delivered Jacob to utter destruction,/_and Israel to reviling.

18535.text: §¶But now hear, O Jacob my servant,/_Israel whom I have chosen!

18536.text: /Thus says the Lord who made you,/_who formed you in the womb and will help you:/Do not fear, O Jacob my servant,/_Jeshurun whom I have chosen.

18537.text: /For I will pour water on the thirsty land,/_and streams on the dry ground;/I will pour my spirit upon your descendants,/_and my blessing on your offspring.

18538.text: /They shall spring up like a green tamarisk,/_like willows by flowing streams.

18539.text: /This one will say, “I am the Lord’s,”/_another will be called by the name of Jacob,/yet another will write on the hand, “The Lord’s,”/_and adopt the name of Israel.

18540.text: ¶Thus says the Lord, the King of Israel,/_and his Redeemer, the Lord of hosts:/I am the first and I am the last;/_besides me there is no god.

18541.text: /Who is like me? Let them proclaim it,/_let them declare and set it forth before me./Who has announced from of old the things to come?/_Let them tell us what is yet to be.

18542.text: /Do not fear, or be afraid;/_have I not told you from of old and declared it?/_You are my witnesses!/Is there any god besides me?/_There is no other rock; I know not one.

18543.text: §¶All who make idols are nothing, and the things they delight in do not profit; their witnesses neither see nor know. And so they will be put to shame.

18544.text: Who would fashion a god or cast an image that can do no good?

18545.text: Look, all its devotees shall be put to shame; the artisans too are merely human. Let them all assemble, let them stand up; they shall be terrified, they shall all be put to shame.

18546.text: ¶The ironsmith fashions it and works it over the coals, shaping it with hammers, and forging it with his strong arm; he becomes hungry and his strength fails, he drinks no water and is faint.

18547.text: The carpenter stretches a line, marks it out with a stylus, fashions it with planes, and marks it with a compass; he makes it in human form, with human beauty, to be set up in a shrine.

18548.text: He cuts down cedars or chooses a holm tree or an oak and lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest. He plants a cedar and the rain nourishes it.

18549.text: Then it can be used as fuel. Part of it he takes and warms himself; he kindles a fire and bakes bread. Then he makes a god and worships it, makes it a carved image and bows down before it.

18550.text: Half of it he burns in the fire; over this half he roasts meat, eats it and is satisfied. He also warms himself and says, “Ah, I am warm, I can feel the fire!”

18551.text: The rest of it he makes into a god, his idol, bows down to it and worships it; he prays to it and says, “Save me, for you are my god!”

18552.text: ¶They do not know, nor do they comprehend; for their eyes are shut, so that they cannot see, and their minds as well, so that they cannot understand.

18553.text: No one considers, nor is there knowledge or discernment to say, “Half of it I burned in the fire; I also baked bread on its coals, I roasted meat and have eaten. Now shall I make the rest of it an abomination? Shall I fall down before a block of wood?”

18554.text: He feeds on ashes; a deluded mind has led him astray, and he cannot save himself or say, “Is not this thing in my right hand a fraud?”

18555.text: §¶Remember these things, O Jacob,/_and Israel, for you are my servant;/I formed you, you are my servant;/_O Israel, you will not be forgotten by me.

18556.text: /I have swept away your transgressions like a cloud,/_and your sins like mist;/return to me, for I have redeemed you.

18557.text: ¶Sing, O heavens, for the Lord has done it;/_shout, O depths of the earth;/break forth into singing, O mountains,/_O forest, and every tree in it!/For the Lord has redeemed Jacob,/_and will be glorified in Israel.

18558.text: ¶Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer,/_who formed you in the womb:/I am the Lord, who made all things,/_who alone stretched out the heavens,/_who by myself spread out the earth;

18559.text: /who frustrates the omens of liars,/_and makes fools of diviners;/who turns back the wise,/_and makes their knowledge foolish;

18560.text: /who confirms the word of his servant,/_and fulfills the prediction of his messengers;/who says of Jerusalem, “It shall be inhabited,”/_and of the cities of Judah, “They shall be rebuilt,/_and I will raise up their ruins”;

18561.text: /who says to the deep, “Be dry—/_I will dry up your rivers”;

18562.text: /who says of Cyrus, “He is my shepherd,/_and he shall carry out all my purpose”;/and who says of Jerusalem, “It shall be rebuilt,”/_and of the temple, “Your foundation shall be laid.”

18563.text: §¶Thus says the Lord to his anointed, to Cyrus,/_whose right hand I have grasped/to subdue nations before him/_and strip kings of their robes,/to open doors before him—/_and the gates shall not be closed:

18564.text: /I will go before you/_and level the mountains,/I will break in pieces the doors of bronze/_and cut through the bars of iron,

18565.text: /I will give you the treasures of darkness/_and riches hidden in secret places,/so that you may know that it is I, the Lord,/_the God of Israel, who call you by your name.

18566.text: /For the sake of my servant Jacob,/_and Israel my chosen,/I call you by your name,/_I surname you, though you do not know me.

18567.text: /I am the Lord, and there is no other;/_besides me there is no god./_I arm you, though you do not know me,

18568.text: /so that they may know, from the rising of the sun/_and from the west, that there is no one besides me;/_I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18569.text: /I form light and create darkness,/_I make weal and create woe;/_I the Lord do all these things.

18570.text: ¶Shower, O heavens, from above,/_and let the skies rain down righteousness;/let the earth open, that salvation may spring up,/_and let it cause righteousness to sprout up also;/_I the Lord have created it.

18571.text: ¶Woe to you who strive with your Maker,/_earthen vessels with the potter!/Does the clay say to the one who fashions it, “What are you making”?/_or “Your work has no handles”?

18572.text: /Woe to anyone who says to a father, “What are you begetting?”/_or to a woman, “With what are you in labor?”

18573.text: /Thus says the Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel, and its Maker:/Will you question me about my children,/_or command me concerning the work of my hands?

18574.text: /I made the earth,/_and created humankind upon it;/it was my hands that stretched out the heavens,/_and I commanded all their host.

18575.text: /I have aroused Cyrus in righteousness,/_and I will make all his paths straight;/he shall build my city/_and set my exiles free,/not for price or reward,/_says the Lord of hosts.

18576.text: /Thus says the Lord:/The wealth of Egypt and the merchandise of Ethiopia,/_and the Sabeans, tall of stature,/shall come over to you and be yours,/_they shall follow you;/_they shall come over in chains and bow down to you./They will make supplication to you, saying,/_“God is with you alone, and there is no other;/_there is no god besides him.”

18577.text: /Truly, you are a God who hides himself,/_O God of Israel, the Savior.

18578.text: /All of them are put to shame and confounded,/_the makers of idols go in confusion together.

18579.text: /But Israel is saved by the Lord/_with everlasting salvation;/you shall not be put to shame or confounded/_to all eternity.

18580.text: ¶For thus says the Lord,/who created the heavens/_(he is God!),/who formed the earth and made it/_(he established it;/he did not create it a chaos,/_he formed it to be inhabited!):/I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18581.text: /I did not speak in secret,/_in a land of darkness;/I did not say to the offspring of Jacob,/_“Seek me in chaos.”/I the Lord speak the truth,/_I declare what is right.

18582.text: §¶Assemble yourselves and come together,/_draw near, you survivors of the nations!/They have no knowledge—/_those who carry about their wooden idols,/and keep on praying to a god/_that cannot save.

18583.text: /Declare and present your case;/_let them take counsel together!/Who told this long ago?/_Who declared it of old?/Was it not I, the Lord?/_There is no other god besides me,/a righteous God and a Savior;/_there is no one besides me.

18584.text: ¶Turn to me and be saved,/_all the ends of the earth!/_For I am God, and there is no other.

18585.text: /By myself I have sworn,/_from my mouth has gone forth in righteousness/_a word that shall not return:/“To me every knee shall bow,/_every tongue shall swear.”

18586.text: ¶Only in the Lord, it shall be said of me,/_are righteousness and strength;/all who were incensed against him/_shall come to him and be ashamed.

18587.text: /In the Lord all the offspring of Israel/_shall triumph and glory.

18588.text: ¶Bel bows down, Nebo stoops,/_their idols are on beasts and cattle;/these things you carry are loaded/_as burdens on weary animals.

18589.text: /They stoop, they bow down together;/_they cannot save the burden,/_but themselves go into captivity.

18590.text: ¶Listen to me, O house of Jacob,/_all the remnant of the house of Israel,/who have been borne by me from your birth,/_carried from the womb;

18591.text: /even to your old age I am he,/_even when you turn gray I will carry you./I have made, and I will bear;/_I will carry and will save.

18592.text: ¶To whom will you liken me and make me equal,/_and compare me, as though we were alike?

18593.text: /Those who lavish gold from the purse,/_and weigh out silver in the scales—/they hire a goldsmith, who makes it into a god;/_then they fall down and worship!

18594.text: /They lift it to their shoulders, they carry it,/_they set it in its place, and it stands there;/_it cannot move from its place./If one cries out to it, it does not answer/_or save anyone from trouble.

18595.text: ¶Remember this and consider,/_recall it to mind, you transgressors,

18596.text: /_remember the former things of old;/for I am God, and there is no other;/_I am God, and there is no one like me,

18597.text: /declaring the end from the beginning/_and from ancient times things not yet done,/saying, “My purpose shall stand,/_and I will fulfill my intention,”

18598.text: /calling a bird of prey from the east,/_the man for my purpose from a far country./I have spoken, and I will bring it to pass;/_I have planned, and I will do it.

18599.text: ¶Listen to me, you stubborn of heart,/_you who are far from deliverance:

18600.text: /I bring near my deliverance, it is not far off,/_and my salvation will not tarry;/I will put salvation in Zion,/_for Israel my glory.

18601.text: §¶Come down and sit in the dust,/_virgin daughter Babylon!/Sit on the ground without a throne,/_daughter Chaldea!/For you shall no more be called/_tender and delicate.

18602.text: /Take the millstones and grind meal,/_remove your veil,/strip off your robe, uncover your legs,/_pass through the rivers.

18603.text: /Your nakedness shall be uncovered,/_and your shame shall be seen./I will take vengeance,/_and I will spare no one.

18604.text: /Our Redeemer—the Lord of hosts is his name—/_is the Holy One of Israel.

18605.text: ¶Sit in silence, and go into darkness,/_daughter Chaldea!/For you shall no more be called/_the mistress of kingdoms.

18606.text: /I was angry with my people,/_I profaned my heritage;/I gave them into your hand,/_you showed them no mercy;/on the aged you made your yoke/_exceedingly heavy.

18607.text: /You said, “I shall be mistress forever,”/_so that you did not lay these things to heart/_or remember their end.

18608.text: ¶Now therefore hear this, you lover of pleasures,/_who sit securely,/who say in your heart,/_“I am, and there is no one besides me;/I shall not sit as a widow/_or know the loss of children”—

18609.text: /both these things shall come upon you/_in a moment, in one day:/the loss of children and widowhood/_shall come upon you in full measure,/in spite of your many sorceries/_and the great power of your enchantments.

18610.text: ¶You felt secure in your wickedness;/_you said, “No one sees me.”/Your wisdom and your knowledge/_led you astray,/and you said in your heart,/_“I am, and there is no one besides me.”

18611.text: /But evil shall come upon you,/_which you cannot charm away;/disaster shall fall upon you,/_which you will not be able to ward off;/and ruin shall come on you suddenly,/_of which you know nothing.

18612.text: ¶Stand fast in your enchantments/_and your many sorceries,/_with which you have labored from your youth;/perhaps you may be able to succeed,/_perhaps you may inspire terror.

18613.text: /You are wearied with your many consultations;/_let those who study the heavens/stand up and save you,/_those who gaze at the stars,/and at each new moon predict/_what shall befall you.

18614.text: ¶See, they are like stubble,/_the fire consumes them;/they cannot deliver themselves/_from the power of the flame./No coal for warming oneself is this,/_no fire to sit before!

18615.text: /Such to you are those with whom you have labored,/_who have trafficked with you from your youth;/they all wander about in their own paths;/_there is no one to save you.

18616.text: §¶Hear this, O house of Jacob,/_who are called by the name of Israel,/_and who came forth from the loins of Judah;/who swear by the name of the Lord,/_and invoke the God of Israel,/_but not in truth or right.

18617.text: /For they call themselves after the holy city,/_and lean on the God of Israel;/_the Lord of hosts is his name.

18618.text: ¶The former things I declared long ago,/_they went out from my mouth and I made them known;/_then suddenly I did them and they came to pass.

18619.text: /Because I know that you are obstinate,/_and your neck is an iron sinew/_and your forehead brass,

18620.text: /I declared them to you from long ago,/_before they came to pass I announced them to you,/so that you would not say, “My idol did them,/_my carved image and my cast image commanded them.”

18621.text: ¶You have heard; now see all this;/_and will you not declare it?/From this time forward I make you hear new things,/_hidden things that you have not known.

18622.text: /They are created now, not long ago;/_before today you have never heard of them,/_so that you could not say, “I already knew them.”

18623.text: /You have never heard, you have never known,/_from of old your ear has not been opened./For I knew that you would deal very treacherously,/_and that from birth you were called a rebel.

18624.text: ¶For my name’s sake I defer my anger,/_for the sake of my praise I restrain it for you,/_so that I may not cut you off.

18625.text: /See, I have refined you, but not like silver;/_I have tested you in the furnace of adversity.

18626.text: /For my own sake, for my own sake, I do it,/_for why should my name be profaned?/_My glory I will not give to another.

18627.text: ¶Listen to me, O Jacob,/_and Israel, whom I called:/I am He; I am the first,/_and I am the last.

18628.text: /My hand laid the foundation of the earth,/_and my right hand spread out the heavens;/when I summon them,/_they stand at attention.

18629.text: ¶Assemble, all of you, and hear!/_Who among them has declared these things?/The Lord loves him;/_he shall perform his purpose on Babylon,/_and his arm shall be against the Chaldeans.

18630.text: /I, even I, have spoken and called him,/_I have brought him, and he will prosper in his way.

18631.text: /Draw near to me, hear this!/_From the beginning I have not spoken in secret,/_from the time it came to be I have been there./And now the Lord God has sent me and his spirit.

18632.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/I am the Lord your God,/_who teaches you for your own good,/_who leads you in the way you should go.

18633.text: /O that you had paid attention to my commandments!/_Then your prosperity would have been like a river,/_and your success like the waves of the sea;

18634.text: /your offspring would have been like the sand,/_and your descendants like its grains;/their name would never be cut off/_or destroyed from before me.

18635.text: ¶Go out from Babylon, flee from Chaldea,/_declare this with a shout of joy, proclaim it,/send it forth to the end of the earth;/_say, “The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob!”

18636.text: /They did not thirst when he led them through the deserts;/_he made water flow for them from the rock;/_he split open the rock and the water gushed out.

18637.text: ¶“There is no peace,” says the Lord, “for the wicked.”

18638.text: §¶Listen to me, O coastlands,/_pay attention, you peoples from far away!/The Lord called me before I was born,/_while I was in my mother’s womb he named me.

18639.text: /He made my mouth like a sharp sword,/_in the shadow of his hand he hid me;/he made me a polished arrow,/_in his quiver he hid me away.

18640.text: /And he said to me, “You are my servant,/_Israel, in whom I will be glorified.”

18641.text: /But I said, “I have labored in vain,/_I have spent my strength for nothing and vanity;/yet surely my cause is with the Lord,/_and my reward with my God.”

18642.text: ¶And now the Lord says,/_who formed me in the womb to be his servant,/to bring Jacob back to him,/_and that Israel might be gathered to him,/for I am honored in the sight of the Lord,/_and my God has become my strength—

18643.text: /he says,/“It is too light a thing that you should be my servant/_to raise up the tribes of Jacob/_and to restore the survivors of Israel;/I will give you as a light to the nations,/_that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth.”

18644.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_the Redeemer of Israel and his Holy One,/to one deeply despised, abhorred by the nations,/_the slave of rulers,/“Kings shall see and stand up,/_princes, and they shall prostrate themselves,/because of the Lord, who is faithful,/_the Holy One of Israel, who has chosen you.”

18645.text: §¶Thus says the Lord:/In a time of favor I have answered you,/_on a day of salvation I have helped you;/I have kept you and given you/_as a covenant to the people,/to establish the land,/_to apportion the desolate heritages;

18646.text: /saying to the prisoners, “Come out,”/_to those who are in darkness, “Show yourselves.”/They shall feed along the ways,/_on all the bare heights shall be their pasture;

18647.text: /they shall not hunger or thirst,/_neither scorching wind nor sun shall strike them down,/for he who has pity on them will lead them,/_and by springs of water will guide them.

18648.text: /And I will turn all my mountains into a road,/_and my highways shall be raised up.

18649.text: /Lo, these shall come from far away,/_and lo, these from the north and from the west,/_and these from the land of Syene.

18650.text: ¶Sing for joy, O heavens, and exult, O earth;/_break forth, O mountains, into singing!/For the Lord has comforted his people,/_and will have compassion on his suffering ones.

18651.text: ¶But Zion said, “The Lord has forsaken me,/_my Lord has forgotten me.”

18652.text: /Can a woman forget her nursing child,/_or show no compassion for the child of her womb?/Even these may forget,/_yet I will not forget you.

18653.text: /See, I have inscribed you on the palms of my hands;/_your walls are continually before me.

18654.text: /Your builders outdo your destroyers,/_and those who laid you waste go away from you.

18655.text: /Lift up your eyes all around and see;/_they all gather, they come to you./As I live, says the Lord,/_you shall put all of them on like an ornament,/_and like a bride you shall bind them on.

18656.text: ¶Surely your waste and your desolate places/_and your devastated land—/surely now you will be too crowded for your inhabitants,/_and those who swallowed you up will be far away.

18657.text: /The children born in the time of your bereavement/_will yet say in your hearing:/“The place is too crowded for me;/_make room for me to settle.”

18658.text: /Then you will say in your heart,/_“Who has borne me these?/I was bereaved and barren,/_exiled and put away—/_so who has reared these?/I was left all alone—/_where then have these come from?”

18659.text: ¶Thus says the Lord God:/I will soon lift up my hand to the nations,/_and raise my signal to the peoples;/and they shall bring your sons in their bosom,/_and your daughters shall be carried on their shoulders.

18660.text: /Kings shall be your foster fathers,/_and their queens your nursing mothers./With their faces to the ground they shall bow down to you,/_and lick the dust of your feet./Then you will know that I am the Lord;/_those who wait for me shall not be put to shame.

18661.text: ¶Can the prey be taken from the mighty,/_or the captives of a tyrant be rescued?

18662.text: /But thus says the Lord:/Even the captives of the mighty shall be taken,/_and the prey of the tyrant be rescued;/for I will contend with those who contend with you,/_and I will save your children.

18663.text: /I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh,/_and they shall be drunk with their own blood as with wine./Then all flesh shall know/_that I am the Lord your Savior,/_and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.

18664.text: ¶Thus says the Lord:/Where is your mother’s bill of divorce/_with which I put her away?/Or which of my creditors is it/_to whom I have sold you?/No, because of your sins you were sold,/_and for your transgressions your mother was put away.

18665.text: /Why was no one there when I came?/_Why did no one answer when I called?/Is my hand shortened, that it cannot redeem?/_Or have I no power to deliver?/By my rebuke I dry up the sea,/_I make the rivers a desert;/their fish stink for lack of water,/_and die of thirst.

18666.text: /I clothe the heavens with blackness,/_and make sackcloth their covering.

18667.text: §¶The Lord God has given me/_the tongue of a teacher,/that I may know how to sustain/_the weary with a word./Morning by morning he wakens—/_wakens my ear/_to listen as those who are taught.

18668.text: /The Lord God has opened my ear,/_and I was not rebellious,/_I did not turn backward.

18669.text: /I gave my back to those who struck me,/_and my cheeks to those who pulled out the beard;/I did not hide my face/_from insult and spitting.

18670.text: ¶The Lord God helps me;/_therefore I have not been disgraced;/therefore I have set my face like flint,/_and I know that I shall not be put to shame;

18671.text: /_he who vindicates me is near./Who will contend with me?/_Let us stand up together./Who are my adversaries?/_Let them confront me.

18672.text: /It is the Lord God who helps me;/_who will declare me guilty?/All of them will wear out like a garment;/_the moth will eat them up.

18673.text: ¶Who among you fears the Lord/_and obeys the voice of his servant,/who walks in darkness/_and has no light,/yet trusts in the name of the Lord/_and relies upon his God?

18674.text: /But all of you are kindlers of fire,/_lighters of firebrands./Walk in the flame of your fire,/_and among the brands that you have kindled!/This is what you shall have from my hand:/_you shall lie down in torment.

18675.text: §¶Listen to me, you that pursue righteousness,/_you that seek the Lord./Look to the rock from which you were hewn,/_and to the quarry from which you were dug.

18676.text: /Look to Abraham your father/_and to Sarah who bore you;/for he was but one when I called him,/_but I blessed him and made him many.

18677.text: /For the Lord will comfort Zion;/_he will comfort all her waste places,/and will make her wilderness like Eden,/_her desert like the garden of the Lord;/joy and gladness will be found in her,/_thanksgiving and the voice of song.

18678.text: ¶Listen to me, my people,/_and give heed to me, my nation;/for a teaching will go out from me,/_and my justice for a light to the peoples.

18679.text: /I will bring near my deliverance swiftly,/_my salvation has gone out/_and my arms will rule the peoples;/the coastlands wait for me,/_and for my arm they hope.

18680.text: /Lift up your eyes to the heavens,/_and look at the earth beneath;/for the heavens will vanish like smoke,/_the earth will wear out like a garment,/_and those who live on it will die like gnats;/but my salvation will be forever,/_and my deliverance will never be ended.

18681.text: ¶Listen to me, you who know righteousness,/_you people who have my teaching in your hearts;/do not fear the reproach of others,/_and do not be dismayed when they revile you.

18682.text: /For the moth will eat them up like a garment,/_and the worm will eat them like wool;/but my deliverance will be forever,/_and my salvation to all generations.

18683.text: ¶Awake, awake, put on strength,/_O arm of the Lord!/Awake, as in days of old,/_the generations of long ago!/Was it not you who cut Rahab in pieces,/_who pierced the dragon?

18684.text: /Was it not you who dried up the sea,/_the waters of the great deep;/who made the depths of the sea a way/_for the redeemed to cross over?

18685.text: /So the ransomed of the Lord shall return,/_and come to Zion with singing;/everlasting joy shall be upon their heads;/_they shall obtain joy and gladness,/_and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.

18686.text: ¶I, I am he who comforts you;/_why then are you afraid of a mere mortal who must die,/_a human being who fades like grass?

18687.text: /You have forgotten the Lord, your Maker,/_who stretched out the heavens/_and laid the foundations of the earth./You fear continually all day long/_because of the fury of the oppressor,/who is bent on destruction./_But where is the fury of the oppressor?

18688.text: /The oppressed shall speedily be released;/_they shall not die and go down to the Pit,/_nor shall they lack bread.

18689.text: /For I am the Lord your God,/_who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—/_the Lord of hosts is his name.

18690.text: /I have put my words in your mouth,/_and hidden you in the shadow of my hand,/stretching out the heavens/_and laying the foundations of the earth,/_and saying to Zion, “You are my people.”

18691.text: ¶Rouse yourself, rouse yourself!/_Stand up, O Jerusalem,/you who have drunk at the hand of the Lord/_the cup of his wrath,/who have drunk to the dregs/_the bowl of staggering.

18692.text: /There is no one to guide her/_among all the children she has borne;/there is no one to take her by the hand/_among all the children she has brought up.

18693.text: /These two things have befallen you/_—who will grieve with you?—/devastation and destruction, famine and sword—/_who will comfort you?

18694.text: /Your children have fainted,/_they lie at the head of every street/_like an antelope in a net;/they are full of the wrath of the Lord,/_the rebuke of your God.

18695.text: ¶Therefore hear this, you who are wounded,/_who are drunk, but not with wine:

18696.text: /Thus says your Sovereign, the Lord,/_your God who pleads the cause of his people:/See, I have taken from your hand the cup of staggering;/you shall drink no more/_from the bowl of my wrath.

18697.text: /And I will put it into the hand of your tormentors,/_who have said to you,/_“Bow down, that we may walk on you”;/and you have made your back like the ground/_and like the street for them to walk on.

18698.text: §¶Awake, awake,/_put on your strength, O Zion!/Put on your beautiful garments,/_O Jerusalem, the holy city;/for the uncircumcised and the unclean/_shall enter you no more.

18699.text: /Shake yourself from the dust, rise up,/_O captive Jerusalem;/loose the bonds from your neck,/_O captive daughter Zion!

18700.text: ¶For thus says the Lord: You were sold for nothing, and you shall be redeemed without money.

18701.text: For thus says the Lord God: Long ago, my people went down into Egypt to reside there as aliens; the Assyrian, too, has oppressed them without cause.

18702.text: Now therefore what am I doing here, says the Lord, seeing that my people are taken away without cause? Their rulers howl, says the Lord, and continually, all day long, my name is despised.

18703.text: Therefore my people shall know my name; therefore in that day they shall know that it is I who speak; here am I.

18704.text: ¶How beautiful upon the mountains/_are the feet of the messenger who announces peace,/who brings good news,/_who announces salvation,/_who says to Zion, “Your God reigns.”

18705.text: /Listen! Your sentinels lift up their voices,/_together they sing for joy;/for in plain sight they see/_the return of the Lord to Zion.

18706.text: /Break forth together into singing,/_you ruins of Jerusalem;/for the Lord has comforted his people,/_he has redeemed Jerusalem.

18707.text: /The Lord has bared his holy arm/_before the eyes of all the nations;/and all the ends of the earth shall see/_the salvation of our God.

18708.text: ¶Depart, depart, go out from there!/_Touch no unclean thing;/go out from the midst of it, purify yourselves,/_you who carry the vessels of the Lord.

18709.text: /For you shall not go out in haste,/_and you shall not go in flight;/for the Lord will go before you,/_and the God of Israel will be your rear guard.

18710.text: §¶See, my servant shall prosper;/_he shall be exalted and lifted up,/_and shall be very high.

18711.text: /Just as there were many who were astonished at him/_—so marred was his appearance, beyond human semblance,/_and his form beyond that of mortals—

18712.text: /so he shall startle many nations;/_kings shall shut their mouths because of him;/for that which had not been told them they shall see,/_and that which they had not heard they shall contemplate.

18713.text: /Who has believed what we have heard?/_And to whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed?

18714.text: /For he grew up before him like a young plant,/_and like a root out of dry ground;/he had no form or majesty that we should look at him,/_nothing in his appearance that we should desire him.

18715.text: /He was despised and rejected by others;/_a man of suffering and acquainted with infirmity;/and as one from whom others hide their faces/_he was despised, and we held him of no account.

18716.text: ¶Surely he has borne our infirmities/_and carried our diseases;/yet we accounted him stricken,/_struck down by God, and afflicted.

18717.text: /But he was wounded for our transgressions,/_crushed for our iniquities;/upon him was the punishment that made us whole,/_and by his bruises we are healed.

18718.text: /All we like sheep have gone astray;/_we have all turned to our own way,/and the Lord has laid on him/_the iniquity of us all.

18719.text: ¶He was oppressed, and he was afflicted,/_yet he did not open his mouth;/like a lamb that is led to the slaughter,/_and like a sheep that before its shearers is silent,/_so he did not open his mouth.

18720.text: /By a perversion of justice he was taken away./_Who could have imagined his future?/For he was cut off from the land of the living,/_stricken for the transgression of my people.

18721.text: /They made his grave with the wicked/_and his tomb with the rich,/although he had done no violence,/_and there was no deceit in his mouth.

18722.text: ¶Yet it was the will of the Lord to crush him with pain./When you make his life an offering for sin,/_he shall see his offspring, and shall prolong his days;/through him the will of the Lord shall prosper.

18723.text: /_Out of his anguish he shall see light;/he shall find satisfaction through his knowledge./_The righteous one, my servant, shall make many righteous,/_and he shall bear their iniquities.

18724.text: /Therefore I will allot him a portion with the great,/_and he shall divide the spoil with the strong;/because he poured out himself to death,/_and was numbered with the transgressors;/yet he bore the sin of many,/_and made intercession for the transgressors.

18725.text: §¶Sing, O barren one who did not bear;/_burst into song and shout,/_you who have not been in labor!/For the children of the desolate woman will be more/_than the children of her that is married, says the Lord.
